Institution The University of Kentucky was founded in 1865 as the "Kentucky State Agricultural and Mechanical College" a part of Kentu cky University (now Transylvania University, Lexington, Kentucky). In 1878, the College was separated from Kentucky University under the land grant provision of the federal Morrill Land-Grant College Act of 1862 and established on a 50-acre site donated by the city of Lexington. In 1908, the College was renamed the State University, Lexington, Kentucky, and in 1916, it became the University of Kentucky. The Albert B. Chandler Medical Center was created in 1956, and the Colleges of Medicine, Dentis try, and Nursing were established. The Colleges of Allied Health Professions and Pharmacy were added in 1966 and a School of Public Health was added in 2000. In 1964, development of a statewide community college system was initiated as part of the University. In 1982, the University was organized into three chancellor -lead sectors, the Medical Center, the Lexington Campus, and the Community Colleges, together with a Central Administration. On July 1, 2011, Eli Capilouto DMD, ScD became the 12th president of the University of Kentucky (UK). President Capilouto has led the process to enrich UK's academic experience by investing in priorities that maintain affordability and access; support the institution's talented faculty and staff; and revitalize the living, learning and research facilities across campus. Even during a pandemic, UK has been able to continue efforts for a significant physical transformation of its academic, research, residential, health care and community spaces. Through partnership, increased philanthropy and effective financial management, UK is self -financing the vast majority of its more than $2 billion infrastructure development. Under President Capilouto's leadership, the $3.7 billion flagship and land grant research University has gained significant momentum in fulfilling its multi -faceted mission of teaching, research, service, and health care. UK developed a new strategic plan with input from the entire c ampus for the years 2020-2025. Today, the University of Kentucky supports more than 30,000 students in over 200 academic programs integrated in 16 degree- granting colleges, the Lewis Honors College, the Graduate School, and the UK Library system. The Univ ersity offers 88 bachelor's level, 93 master's level and more than 60 doctoral, specialist and professional degree programs. Students may select from programs in Agriculture, Allied Health Professions, Architecture, Arts and Sciences, Business and Economic s, Communications and Information Studies, Education, Engineering, Fine Arts, Human Environmental Sciences and Social Work. In addition, many students may select from professional programs in Dentistry, Law, Medicine, Nursing, Pharmacy and Public Health. On a national level, UK has consistently ranked among the top 60 to 70 institutions based on total federal obligations, and currently ranks 30th in the country in National Institutes of Health research funding among public institutions. In 1987 and 1994, the University of Kentucky was classified as a Research I institution by the Carnegie Foundation; it is currently ranked 32nd among public research institutions in the nation. To date, the University has received nearly 100 national rankings for excellence in academics, research, health care, and economic development. U.S. News and World Report ranks several of UK's graduate programs among the nation's best, including Business Administration, Clinical Laboratory Sciences, Economics, Nursing, Pharm acy, Physical Therapy and Public Policy. Academic Medical Center and UK Healthcare Responding to warnings that the state would face a serious shortage of medical caregivers in the near future, Kentucky legislators authorized the construction of a medical center at the University of Kentucky in 1956. The new facility would provide state- of-the-art care to all Kentucky residents, regardless of their ability to pay. Progressive Kentuckians who had lobbied for a new hospital and medical school for several deca des saw the legislators' decision to fund the project as a great victory for the state. When dignitaries convened on a farm bordering the University campus for the groundbreaking ceremony in December 1957, then University President Frank Dickey acknowledged the significance of the event, declaring it a "never to be forgotten day" in Kentucky's history. ii The UK Healthcare (UKHC) clinical enterprise is the umbrella organization for the UK Medical Center (UKMC), with over 9,000 employees serving the most critically injured and ill patients in the Commonwealth and beyond in over 1,000 beds at Albert B. Chandler Hospital, the UK Children's Hospital, UK Samaritan Hospital, Eastern State Hospital, and multiple ambulatory clinics. With nearly 4 0,000 discharges in 2019, Albert B. Chandler Hospital includes the only Level 1 Trauma Center for both adult and pediatric patients in Central and Eastern Kentucky. UKMC also includes the Colleges of Nursing, Medicine, Dentistry, Health Sciences, Pharmacy, Public Health and Social Work. In addition, UKHC is closely affiliated with the Veteran's Affairs Medical Center (VAMC). The VAMC has two locations: the Cooper Drive division, which is physically linked to the Albert B. Chandler Hospital, houses the acute medical, psychiatric, surgical and neurological units, intensive care units and numerous specialty clinics; and the Leestown division, which houses the long -term units. UKMC and VAMC share resources such as medical equipment, and many physicians hold join t appointments at both institutions. The College of Nursing Dr. Marcia Dake, the first Dean of the College of Nursing (1960- 1971), came to the University of Kentucky with a vision to inspire faculty to create innovative programs that would serve as a model for higher education in nursing. Enrollment for BSN education more than doubled from 35 in 1960 to 74 in 1962, and in 1970 an MSN program was opened. Deans that followed continued to prepare thousands of nurses; men and women to lead as caregivers, educators, researchers, policymakers, community transformers and executive leaders. Dr. Marion A. McKenna (1971 to 1984) and Dr. Carolyn A. Williams (1984 to 2006) established doctoral programs (PhD in 1987; the first DNP in the country in 2001) and Dr. Jane Kirschling (2006 to 2012) established the first interprofessional health education programming for the University of Kentucky. In 2014, Janie Heath, PhD, APRN -BC, FAAN, FNAP, FAANP, was appointed the sixth Dean of the College of Nursing (CON), and continues to build on hallmarks of academic excellence through education, practice, service and research. She is actively engaged with UKHC, the UK Center for Interprofessional Health Education (CIHE) and numerous academic clinical partners in the Commonwealth and beyond to assure that the CON meets the needs of those it serves. In Dean Heath's first three years, the CON developed a new s trategic plan in conjunction with the new UK strategic plan, as well as reviewed and revised the mission, vision, and values statements. She also reorganized the CON administrative academic structure by adding developmental leadership roles, securing funding to expand and renovate research space, and increasing undergraduate and graduate enrollment, academic clinical partnerships, faculty practice agreements and program outreach initiatives. In 2020, the CON became designated as one of the Na tional League of Nursing (NLN) Centers for Nursing Education Excellence for initiatives that impact four -degree programs (BSN, MSN, DNP and PhD) and post - graduate APRN certificate. The baccalaureate program has been accredited by CCNE since 1999, the DNP since 2009 and the MSN and post -master's certificates are under review for 2021. The CON received recognition of "distinction" as a provider of continuing nursing education by the American Nurses Credentialing Center's Commission on Accreditation 2015- 2020. The CON has a current enrollment of 813 BSN students, 483 Pre-Nursing students, 15 MSN students, 28 PhD students, 157 DNP students and 16 Post -Graduate APRN Certificate students. Currently, 68 full- time faculty and/or faculty administrators are employed in the CON, of whom 85% (58) have an earned doctorate, 29% (20) serve in an active faculty practice and 37% (25) are honored as fellows in various societies/organizations. Administrative Organization The Dean of the College reports to the Provost of the University. The CON's administrative structure includes the Dean, Senior Associate Dean, Associate Dean of Undergraduate Faculty and Interprofessional HealthCare Education (IPE) Affairs, Associate Dean for the MSN, DNP and Post-Graduate APRN Certif icate Faculty and Practice Affairs, Associate Dean of Research and PhD Faculty Affairs, Associate Dean of Executive Administrative Operations and Finance and six assistant deans as reflected in Table 1 College of Nursing Organizational Chart. Each degree- offering program has an Assistant Dean to help support the respective Associate Dean's responsibilities in selected areas such as program growth, curricular innovation, student learning, clinical affairs, and faculty scholarly affairs. All full -time faculty are evaluated by an Associate Dean and are assigned to work closely with an Assistant Dean based on the program of study in which they have their primary teaching assignment. iii Table 1: College of Nursing Organizational Chart As illustrated in Table 1: CON Organizational Chart shows the integration of executive- level management with UKHC. There are congruent lines of communication between the CON Dean and the UKHC Chief Nurse Executive, and the UKHC Executive Vice President for Health affairs. Likewise, the CON Dean is included in the organizational chart for UK Health care Nursing as a top -level administrator. UKHC Nursing Organizational Chart available in the Virtual Resource Room . The UKHC Chief Nurse Executive regularly attends the CON Faculty Organization meetings to provide updates that could impact the CON. Self-Study Process All full-time faculty, professional staff, administrators, and key clinical/community partners participated in the self -study process. Undergraduate and graduate students were engaged in the self -study process through representation on academic program committees and/or student governance committees/advisory boards. The process began in 2018, with an official launch in August 2019 with the Dean, Associate and Assistant Deans' retreat to review the intent of the self -study process, as a part of the College's approach to on -going and continuous quality improvement. Monthly meetings have continued to assure completion of the self-study. Data presented in the self -study relate to academic years 2017 -2018, 2018 -2019, 2019- 2020, and fall, 2020. Data for spring 2021 are available upon request as appropriate. 1 Standard I Program Quality: Mission and Governance The mission, goals, and expected program outcomes are congruent with those of the parent institution, reflect professional nursing standards and guidelines, and consider the needs and expectations of the community of interest. Policies of the parent institution and nursing program clearly support the program' s mission, goals, and expected outcomes. The faculty and students of the program are involved in the governance of the program and in the ongoing efforts to improve program quality. I-A. The mission, goals, and expected program outcomes are: congruent wit h those of the parent institution; and reviewed periodically and revised as appropriate Elaboration: The program's mission, goals, and expected program outcomes are written and accessible to current and prospective students, faculty, and other constituents. Program outcomes include student outcomes, faculty outcomes, and other outcomes identified by the program. The mission may relate to all nursing programs offered by the nursing unit, or specific programs may have separate missions. Program goals are clearly differentiated by level when multiple degree/certificate programs exist. Expected program outcomes may be expressed as competencies, objectives, benchmarks, or other terminology congruent with institutional and program norms. There is a defined process for periodic review and revision of program mission, goals, and expected program outcomes that has been implemented, as appropriate. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element The mission, goals and expected program outcomes of the College of Nursing (CON) are congruent with those of the parent institution, University of Kentucky (UK), as reflected in Table IA -1: Congruency between the Missions of UK and the CON. The CON mission and values are reviewed every five years or as needed to be consistent with UK. The faculty organization reviews and approves any indicated changes. The Mission of UK is a public land-grant university dedicated to improving peoples' lives through excellence in education, research and creative work, service and health care. As Kentucky's flagship institution, the University plays a critical leadership role by promoting diversity, inclusion, economic development, and human well-being. The CON Mission is to promote health and well -being through excellence in nursing e ducation, research, practice and service while fostering diversity and inclusion. The CON values statement is to promote a healthy learning and working environment to ensure a high l evel of professionalism, civility, and caring among students, staff, and faculty. As Kentucky's flagship institution, the University plays a critical leadership role by promoting diversity, inclusion, economic development, and human well -being. The U niversity of Kentucky: Facilitates learning, informed by scholarship and research. Expands knowledge through research, The mission of the University of Kentucky College of Nursing is to p romote health and well -being through excellence in nursing education, research, practice, and service while fostering diversity and inclusion. The College of Nursing will be one of the nation's top nursing programs in education, research, practice, and service. 2 scholarship, and creative activity; and Serves a global community by disseminating, sharing, and applying knowledge. U Unique and innovative contributions to healthcare K Knowledge and evidence- based practice C Collaborative and diverse learning environments O Open and respectful relationships N Nursing leadership and recognition The mission and expected program learning outcomes of the nursing programs are related to the mission and goals of UK and the CON. Development of student outcomes has been guided by the mission and goals of UK and the CON, as well as nationally -recognized competencies. The goals and expected student outcomes are published annually in the CON's Student Handbooks and are available on the CON website. The professional standards, guidelines, and competencies that guide the educational programs of the CON were chosen because they reflect the best and most contemporary thinking and represen t the views of an increasingly diverse practice discipline and public; these are listed in Table IB-1: Selected Standards, Guidelines and Competencies. The mission, goals and expected student outcomes of the CON are reviewed according to the timeline outlined in the CON Systematic Process for Program Effectiveness (SPPE) . The SPPE was developed as an assessment guide for administrators, program directors, course coordinators and faculty as they periodically conduct formative and summative systematic program evaluations. The plan was designed in a format that would assure compliance with CCNE standards, Kentucky Board of Nursing requirements, and the Strategic Plan goals. It also identifies who is responsible, where the data can be found and the timeline for evaluation. The CON mission, goals, and expected student outcomes are reviewed as each new UK strategic plan is proposed and at other times as needed to improve educational preparation for graduates. For example, reviews were implemented when professional nursing standards changed so that the AACN -revised Essentials were incorporated into the curricula. Also, the mission, goals, and expected student outcomes are reviewed when there is a major change in UK requirements, such as the recent UK Core (General Education) changes. The mission and goals were approved in 2015. The mission and goals were reaffirmed by the faculty prior to beginning the work on the CON strategic plan in 2018. I-B. The mission, goals, and expected program outcomes are consis tent with relevant professional nursing standards and guidelines for the preparation of nursing professionals. Elaboration: The program identifies the professional nursing standards and guidelines it uses. CCNE requires, as appropriate, the following professional nursing standards and guidelines: The Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice [American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN), 2008]; The Essentials of Master's Education in Nursing (AACN, 2011); The Essentials of Doctoral Education for Advanced Nursing Practice (AACN, 2006); and Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs [National Task Force on Quality Nurse Practitioner Edu cation (NTF), 2016]. A program may select additional standards and guidelines that are current and relevant to program offerings. A program preparing students for certification incorporates professional standards and guidelines appropriate to the role/area of education. An APRN education program (degree or certificate) prepares students for one of the four APRN roles and in at least one population focus, in accordance with the Consensus Model for APRN Regulation: 3 Licensure, Accreditation, Certification and Education (July 2008). Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON has incorporated Professional Nursing Standards and Guidelines (PNSG) into the BSN, MSN, and DNP programs. Table IB -1: Selected Standards, Guidelines and Competencies , lists selected key professional nursing standards and guidelines the CON follows for the preparation of nursing professionals. The commitment to professional standards is evident in the mission, values, and program outcomes of the CON. The CON works to instill the importan ce of the professional standards across all programs. The BSN program comprises three BSN tracks, including: (1) four -year Traditional; (2) Accelerated Second Degree (ABSN); and (3) RN -BSN Online. The MSN program is organized into one area of concentration (Healthcare Systems Leadership). The DNP (BSN- to-DNP or MSN- to-DNP) program comprises seven including: (1) Adult Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner; (2) Family Nurse Practitioner; (3) Pediatric Acute Care Nurse Practitioner; (4) Pediatric Primary Care Nurse Practitioner; (5) Psychiatric -Mental Health Nurse Practitioner; (6) Executive Leadership in Health Care; and (7) Clinical Leadership in Health Care. Our Post -Graduate APRN Certificate program comprises six areas, including: (1) Adult Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner; (2) Family Nurse Practitioner; (3) Pediatric Acute Care Nurse Practitioner; (4) Pediatric Primary Care Nurse Practitioner; (5) Psychiatric -Mental Health Nurse Practitioner; and (6) Executive Leadership in Healthcare Certificate. Evidence includes the requirement for DNP students being asked to include exemplars that address each of the program outcomes on their portfolios. (Crosswalk Available in the Virtual Resource Room) I-C. The mission, goals, and expected program outcomes reflect the needs and expectations of the community of interest. Elaboration: The community of interest is defined by the nursing unit. The needs and expectations of the community of interest are considered in the periodic review of the mission, goals, and expected program outcomes. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON Community of Interest (COI) is defined as both internal and external entities which directly or indirectly interface with the CON. The COI includes students, staff, faculty of the CON, alumni, Emeriti faculty and staff, Dean's Advisory Board, Dean's Diversity and Inclusivity Advisory Board, College of Nursing Alumni Association, benefactors, and supporters. The Dean's Advisory Board meets biannually with the stated purpose of providing counsel to the D ean on critical matters as well as long -range planning and philanthropic endeavors. As illustrated in Table 1C -1: Dean's Advisory Board , membership is comprised of alumni, supporters and students who collectively represent a diverse and comprehensive expertise and will serve as an advocacy network and as ambassadors for the College of Nursing, increasing awareness of the College in Kentucky and across the nation. In addition, the CON Dean works closely with University administration and UK Healthcare administration to align institutional goals, budget expectations and academic clinical agreements. Faculty provide feedback through surveys and participation in the CON Faculty Organization, CON standing committees, and Dean task force meetings. Input from the student community of interest is ascertained through several venues, which include representation on CON standing committees, graduating students' CON End-of-Program Survey and Dean's Advisory Board. Alumni provide feedback to the CON through a variety of ways: (1) the CON Alumni Association meetings; (2) the CON and UK HealthCare Academic Practice Quarterly Committee Meetings to respond to their level satisfaction or concerns related to educational preparation; and 5 (3) Dean's Advisory Boards, speak on industry topics, and have opportunities to gather at regional alumni events. These activities allow alumni to stay connected to the school, provide feedback on the types of program they are interested in, inform current students o n industry changes, and have a sense of community with fellow nursing alumni. The Board of Directors meets biannually in addition to annually during the University's Homecoming weekend with the membership. I-D. The nursing unit's expectations for faculty are written and communicated to the faculty and are congruent with institutional expectations Elaboration : Expectations for faculty are congruent with those of the parent institution. The nursing unit's expectations for faculty, whether in teaching, scholarship, service, practice, or other areas, may vary for different groups of faculty (full -time, part -time, adjunct, tenured, non-tenured, or other). Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key El ement. Faculty members are defined in the UK Administrative Regulations according to title series of appointment. Expected faculty outcomes within these definitions are consistent with the expectations of UK. Faculty members' expectations regarding teaching, scholarship, service, or practice vary according to their title 7 series. The CON follows the University's administrative rules and uses the following title series: Lecture Title Series (non -tenure; faculty outcomes primarily focused on meeting UK goals and student outcomes related to teaching); Clinical Title Series (non -tenure; faculty outcomes primarily focused on meeting UK goals related to practice and student outcomes related to teaching); Research Title Series (non -tenure; faculty outcomes primarily focused on meeting UK goals related to scholarship and research); Special Title Series (tenure; faculty outcomes primarily focused on meeting UK goals related to practice, scholarship and service, and student outcomes related to teaching); and Regular Title Series (tenure; faculty outcomes primarily focused on meeting UK goals related to teaching, scholarship, research and service, and student outcomes related to teaching) (See CON Faculty Workload and CON Faculty Evaluation and Workload .) Currently, the CON criteria for appointment, promotion, and tenure remains in alignment for respective title series that are congruent with UK's and are provided in the UK Administrative Regulations . New facult y members participate in both UK and CON new faculty orientation throughout their first year to ensure that faculty member outcomes are congruent with the mission, goals and expected outcomes. Non -tenured faculty members are reviewed annually and tenured faculty and senior lecturers biannually with "mini -reviews for progress on goals" on alternating years, by their reporting supervisor. The review includes a requirement by faculty members to provide evidence that they are meeting the expectations o f their respective roles in the CON. Tenure- track faculty undergo a two - and four -year review that includes feedback from tenured faculty. Annually, faculty members negotiate their Distribution of Effort (DOE) in the areas of teaching, scholarship, service, and practice, as appropriate to their title series. The DOE process is University -driven, and the CON DOE process was revised in fall 2016 to ensure its major purpose accurately reflects the time faculty members spend meeting the mission and goals of UK and the CON (faculty exemplar available in the Virtual Resource Room) (See CON Facult y Workload and CON Faculty Evaluation and Workload .) The CON workload assignment for courses and student advising recognizes the time involved in supporting students to achieve the expected student learning and program outcomes. Periodic review and revision of academic programs, research and practice goals with expected student outcomes is the res ponsibility of each program -specific committee, and is guided by the CON Strategic Plan. I-E. Faculty and students participate in program governance. Elaboration: Roles of the faculty and students in the governance of the program, including those involved in distance education, are clearly defined, and promote participation. Nursing faculty are involved in the development, review, and revision of academic program policies. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON faculty members and students participate in the mission and governance of the College and University in a manner that serves to maintain and improve the quality of progra ms of nursing. The CON has structured activities that provide dialogue that leads to continuous evaluation and revision of the nursing programs. The faculty and staff retreats have been successful in providing input into structural, programmatic, and informatics needs within the College. For example, opportunities for input were given to faculty and staff during the development of the 2015- 2020 CON strategic plan and the 2020- 2025 CON strategic plan. The UK Faculty Senate, as the UK-wide faculty organization, is authorized to issue rules implementing the responsibilities delegated to it and authorized by the Governing Regulations. The faculty, administrators and students of the CON participate in the governance of UK, UKHC and CON in accordance with Kentucky state law and the UK Governing Regulations. UK Senate Rules provide for the election of three faculty members from the CON to the UK Senate. In addition, each of the CON's faculty senators serve on a standing UK Senate subcommittee. In addition to informing faculty about Senate activities in faculty organizational meetings, faculty senators obtain input from the CON faculty through open forums or via email as a more timely way to disseminate information to faculty and receive input from faculty on matters for the Senate. Faculty also may participate in UK governance through appointment or election to UK Administrative Committees, other Senate Committees, and Senate Advisory Committees. Currently, faculty serve on multiple UK, UKHC and CON committees . The CON Dean meets with the UK President and Provost, along with the other Deans, at least quarterly 8 and the Provost meets with all Deans bimonthly. During the pandemic, it has been weekly. The purpose of these meetings is general communication regarding the academic aspects at UK. Since 1984, the Dean has participated in UK governance as an ex-officio member of the UK Senate with voting privileges every other year. The Associate Deans also serve various roles in University Governance. For example, the Associate Dean of Research is a member of the UK Research Management Group with the VP of Research, which meets monthly; the Associate Dean for Undergraduate Faculty and IPE Affairs is a member of the UK Center for Interprofess ional Health Education Committee; the Associate Dean for MSN and DNP Faculty and Practice Affairs is a member of the UK Press Committee, and the Executive Associate Dean for the Norton Healthcare Partnership is a member of the Norton Healthcare Nursing Leadership Institute. Faculty members participate in the governance of the CON as provided in the Faculty Bylaws and the Administrative Bylaws . Of the 68 full- time faculty, 85% participated on CON committees in 2020- 2021. The committees constituted by the Faculty Bylaws ensure faculty responsibility for curricular matters as well as admission, progression, and graduation of stu dents. The committees constituted by the Administrative Bylaws provide for faculty input into administrative decision -making in the areas of faculty appointment, promotion and tenure, college development, professional development, and student activities. The faculty as a whole meet at least three times each semester to act on matters affecting education, service, practice, and research. Faculty Organization meetings are led by the chair of the CON Faculty Council. The chair of Faculty Council, along with the Associate Deans, is a key member of the Dean's administrative leadership team. The Dean has provided an open forum to discuss various CON initiatives or challenges, including the impact of the decreased University budget on the CON, reviewing stra tegies to meet the CON's contribution to the University's cost savings plan and the mix of tenure- track and non-tenure track future hires. Since March 2020, the Dean has provided regularly -scheduled Zoom information sessions to disseminate the most recent COVID -19 information from the University as well as the CON's plan to maintain the safety and wellness of students, staff and faculty. Students have an opportunity to participate in the governance of the CON as outlined in the CON Administrative Bylaws and Faculty Bylaws . Undergraduate and graduate student activities and Advisory Committees are elected by their respective student bodies and provide formal feedback to administrators as well as faculty. Students of the CON have the same opportunities to participate in the governance of UK as do students in other units of the University. The primary vehicle for student participation is through each College's Student Government Associations, such as the Undergraduate Nursing Academic Advisory Council ( UNAAC ) and Graduate Nursing Academic Advisory Council (GNAAC ). Each year one student is elected from and by the CON's student body to the Student Government Association and by virtue of this position is also the student representative from the CON to the UK Senate . In addition, students serve on CON academic program committees and leadership from UNAAC and GNAAC serve on the Dean's advisory boards/councils. Students are elected by the CON undergraduate or graduate student body. Leadership for UNAAC includes representation on BSN program committees. Similarly, leadership for GNAAC includes representation on the MSN, DNP and PhD program committees. Undergraduate students also participate in scheduled course meetings throughout the academic year. Student representatives are elected by their classmates to be their representatives at course meetings. The representatives serve as a mechanism to communicate student concerns to faculty, and faculty responses to the students. In addition, the Dean invites randomly selected students to quarterly "Teas with the Dean." These primarily focus on the student experience at UK, diversity and inclusivity, and wellness and belonging. I-F. Academic policies of the parent institution and the nursing program are congruent and support achievement of the mission, go als, and expected program outcomes. These policies are: fair and equitable; published and accessible; and reviewed and revised as necessary to foster program improvement. Elaboration: Academic policies include, but are not limited to, those related to student recruitment, admission, retention, and progression. Policies are written and communicated to relevant constituencies. Policies are implemented consistently. Differences between the nursing program policies and those of the parent institution are identified and support achievement of the program's mission, goals, and expected outcomes. A defined process exists by which policies are regularly reviewed. Policy review occurs, and revisions are made 9 as needed. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. CON academic policies are reviewed and revised as necessary to foster ongoing program improvement. The CON Bylaws and CON policies are available on the CON website and are congruent with UK policies and regulatory bodies such as CCNE and the Kentucky Board of Nursing. CON faculty are involved in the development, review, revision, and approval of academic program policies. Differences between the nursing program policies and those of the parent institution are in support of achievement of the program's mission, goals, and expected outcomes. The CON uses UK policies as a framework for developing specific CON policies; however, standards can be greater than the policies of the parent institution. Policies for the undergraduate students can be found in the Undergraduate Student Handbook and polices for the graduate s tudents can be found in the Graduate Student Handboo k. Policies are written and communicated to relevant constituencies via the website, email, and in- class announcements. Policies are implemented consistently by faculty and administrators in the CON. Policy review occurs and revisions are made as needed and on an annual basis. Student rights and responsibilities are published in the UK Student Rights and Responsibilities Handbook on the UK website. I-G. The program defines and reviews formal complaints according to established policies. Elaboration: The program defines what constitutes a formal complaint and maintains a record of formal complaints received. The program's definition of formal complaints includes, at a minimum, student complaints. The program's definition of formal complaints and the procedures for filing a complaint are communicated to relevant constituencies. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON follows the policies and procedures of the University regarding resolving student complaints. The CON defines a formal complaint as one which cannot be resolved within the academic unit and CON. Between Fall 2017-2020, there have been two formal complaints by undergraduate students and no formal complaints by graduate students. Within the CON, student issues are directed to the involved party. For example, if students have a concern about a grade in a course or an assignment, they are directed to the course instructor and then to the course coordinator, if applicable. If the issue is not resolved, the student can appeal to the Associate Dean and Assistant Dean of the program in which they are enrolled. If the issue remains unresolved, the student has the option of meeting with the Dean. In addition, all BSN clinical courses have a course representative that can speak about issues on behalf of other students in the course. All students are given access to the online UK Students Rights and Responsibilities and the CON Undergraduate and Graduate Student Handbooks , which contain the necessary policies and procedures for filing a complaint. Formal complaints that cannot be resolved in the CON are directed to the UK Office of Academic Ombudsman Services, which is designated within UK to investigate individual complaints, problems, and conflicts. The Ombud is responsible for assisting students and faculty to work through and resolve academic problems and conflicts. As stated on the website, the primary focus of the academic Ombud services is the process by which decisions are made, and the primary task of the Ombud is to assure fair policies, processes, and procedures that are equitably implemented. Over the past three and half years, the UK Ombud was instrumental in assisting four CON students in resolutions that did not involve a formal UK appeals process, as shown in Table IG -1: Academic Appeals to Ombudsman. (See RR for UK Appeals Process and UK Appeals Board Report . One student complaint, in fall 2019, went through the formal UK appeals process (evidence only available through UK legal). There are currently no CON complaints pending in the UK Office of the Academic Ombud. Non-academic issues are handled according to the appropriate UK policy (e.g., sexual harassment, discrimination ). 10 Table IG -1 Academic Appeals to Ombudsman Semester Complaint Outcome Fall 2017 . Information regarding licensure and/or certification examinations for which graduates will be eligible is accurate. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON's website, student handbooks, recruitment materials, and general descriptive documents are updated annually and as needed during the school year. Each year, Assistant Deans/track coordinators and the Student Services staff for the undergraduate and graduate programs review and update the Undergraduate and Graduate Student Handbooks . The Director of Communications and program administrative assistants make corresponding changes to the CON's website . Announcements regarding new/changed information and policies are communicated to students via their required University email and informational forums designed to receive and give information from/to students regarding updates and programmatic and policy changes. The web page is regularly updated to reflect CON programmatic and policy changes. The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate program curriculum plans, outcome objectives, admission requirements and degree requirements are found on the CON's website . The graduate student handbooks as well as the website has information about the MSN, BSN-DNP track, MSN-DNP track, Post -Graduate APRN Certificate program and the certifications for which our graduate students are eligible following completion of specific programs. 11 The academic calendar and tuition fees are found on UK's website under the Registrar's Office . Transfer of both undergraduate and graduate credits is clearly outlined by UK and the CON. This information is available on both the CON and the UK Registrar's websites. Evaluation criteria and grading policies are published in the syllabus for each course and determined by the faculty teaching the course. Examples available in the Virtual Resource Room. 1 Consensus Model for APRN Regulation: Licensure, Accreditation, Certification and Education (July 2008). 2 Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs (National Task Force on Quality Nurse Practitioner Education, 2016). 12 STANDARD I Summary: Mission and Governance Levels of Strength of Quality Strong Strength of Quality The University of Kentucky has over 156 years of experience as a land -grant, R1 institution with an academic health center and 18 colleges of which 7 are health pro fessions that are located on one campus. The College of Nursing has over 65 years of experience aligned with the mission, vision and strategic initiatives for the University and UK HealthCare . The College of Nursing mission, values, goals, and program outc omes are closely aligned with those of the University of Kentucky. The College of Nursing has a strong academic environment to advance nursing education, faculty practice, collaborative research, and service. The College of Nursing has a strong community o f interest that include internal and external advisory boards composed of members with diverse backgrounds to provide guidance and recommendations on strategic initiatives . Moderate to High Strength of Quality The College of Nursing has a strong faculty and student governance infrastructure with standing committees that provide input on policy development and/or program effectiveness evaluation. The College of Nursing has strong policies and procedures established to address faculty affairs includ ing recruitment, retention, and advancement. The College of Nursing has strong policies and policies established to address student affairs including admission, progression, and retention. Low to Moderate Strength of Quality The College of Nursing recognizes the current capacity of faculty serving on standing committees is stretched and requires on -going efforts to monitor and support. The College of Nursing recognizes the current distribution of effort (DOE) guidelines are not in alignment with the reality of increased demands on teaching/mentoring and transition of faculty for other opportunities (administration/retirement etc.) that r equires on -going efforts to improve. The College of Nursing recognizes the challenges of separate polices for student conduct from the University and the Health Profession Colleges that requires on -going efforts for clarity and better alignment. The Colleg e of Nursing recognizes the faculty governance standing committees composite for tenure- track members will require senior administration efforts for UG faculty to pursue tenure- track position opportunities. The College of Nursing recognizes the ever- changi ng healthcare environment and University demands (mission to serve during pandemic) will require more intentional efforts to obtain alumni input . 13 Standard II Program Quality: Institutional Commitment and Resources The parent institution demonstrates ongoing commitment to and support for the nursing program. The institution makes resources available to enable the program to achieve its mission, goals, and expected outcomes. The faculty and staff, as resources of the program, enable the ach ievement of the mission, goals, and expected program outcomes. II-A. Fiscal resources are sufficient to enable the program to fulfill its mission, goals, and expected outcomes. Adequacy of fiscal resources is reviewed periodically, and resources are modified as needed. Elaboration: The budget enables achievement of the program's mission, goals, and expected outcomes. The budget supports the development, implementation, and evaluation of the program. Compensation of nursing unit personnel supports recruitm ent and retention of faculty and staff. A defined process is used for regular review of the adequacy of the program's fiscal resources. Review of fiscal resources occurs, and modifications are made as appropriate. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON ' s fiscal resources come from several sources, with the majority (62.59%) in 2017- 2018 from the general fund of UK, as shown in Table IIA -1: CON Fiscal Resources . Through 2019- 2020, the College of Nursing had growth in the state allocation; however, the percent of the consolidated budget reflected a decrease of 11.4% to 51.1% (state funding) as other areas, mostly grants, grew. Although fiscal resources at UK supp ort the CON, the continued decline in state support is not a sustainable model and has required the University to implement different funding strategies. The consolidated budget of the University of Kentucky in 2017- 2018 was $3.6B, with steady growth to a (pending) 2020- 2021 $4.4B. The change in the University's operating budget over the last nine years reflects significant efforts to support increased patient care delivery services, increased extramurally -funded research grants and contracts, and a shift in funding from the state to UK students. A balanced, consolidated budget is established prior to the beginning of each fiscal year (July 1 to June 30) and amended during the year as plans change and unanticipated events occur. The University's consolidat ed budget is primarily comprised of four types of current funds: General, Auxiliary, Restricted and Fund Balance. The first three types are recurring funds that are generally received or earned every year, such as state appropriations and tuition and fees revenue. Support from the UK general fund is appropriated annually by the Provost based on the Dean's budget request. The second largest component is from grants and contracts awarded to faculty of the CON for research, training, and capital improvement efforts. The use of these resources is restricted to fulfilling the purpose for which they were awarded. Support from UK HealthCare (UKHC) represents the third largest source of funding. These funds are used to cover the cost of CON faculty and staff who provide the services to complete their work. This source also reflects commitments to the CON from UKHC, which funds a variety of initiatives such as the Post-Baccalaureate Nurse Residency Program (jointly operated with UKHC), several individuals who hold faculty appointments for programmatic n eeds, participate in the College's educational activities, and engage in practice and/or research roles in UKHC. Beginning in 2014- 2015, the College entered a partnership/collaboration with Norton Healthcare to provide DNP education to their BSN -prepared nurses in Louisville, Kentucky. Through this initiative, the general fund budget has grown due to the generation of additional tuition through increased enrollment. For 2020- 2021, the budget for the Norton Partnership is $589,550. In January 2016, the CON began an academic partnership with Select Medical Corporation to provide RN- BSN online classes for up to 50 Select employed, associate degree staff nurses per semester. To date, the Select students are non- residents and University finance modeling doe s not support budget allocation for this 14 partnership. The UK College of Nursing Phyllis D. Corbitt Community Health Center in Wilmore, Kentucky was established on September 14, 2015. The clinic was named for Dr. Corbitt, a family physician who had practiced in Wilmore for over 40 years. The CON Assistant Dean of Faculty Practice, a nurse practitioner with extensive experience, serves as the clinic director. The clinic began as a limited services clinic and evolved to a full, primary care clinic in J une 2019. To date, over 7,500 patient encounters have occurred. The clinic offers an opportunity for primary care APRN faculty to practice and provides a clinical site for BSN and DNP APRN students to earn part of their required 900 clinical hours. The cli nic provides primary care services to patients from infants to elderly. The clinic is an approved site to participate in the federally funded Vaccines for Children's Program. The clinic continues to treat patients with common illnesses such as upper respiratory infections, allergy symptoms, sore throats, and skin infections, in addition to giving immunizations, providing patient education, and counseling as well as school and sports physicals. In April 2020, a full- time RN with a master's in social work was hired. In September 2020, the clinic began offering behavioral health services which have proven to be very beneficial to both patients and staff. Six CON APRN faculty are currently credentialed as clinic providers through the UKHC Medical Staff Affairs Office. At this time, the revenues generated through the clinic cover the costs of personnel and overhead. Beginning in March 2013, a four-year grant from the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services supported a CON women's health nurse practitioner faculty member to implement "Innovation to Care for Perinatal Outcomes in Women at Risk" in the UKHC OB -GYN clinic. New mothers with newborns identified at risk for substance abuse were offered skills to actively manage their recovery, properly parent, and engage in continuing education/job training. In addition, the program offered skills to improve psychosocial health, each critical to long-term recovery. The program later moved from the UKHC OB -GYN Clinic to the UKHC Polk Dalton Clinic, a free-standing clinic located in north Lexington, Kentucky. The program grew with increased grant support until the CON, in collaboration with UKHC, opened the UK Beyond Birth Comprehensive Recovery Clinic on November 8, 2018, a clinic for women with substance use disorders who have recently given birth. This is a comprehensive treatment partnership between UK, UK College of Nursing, UKHC and the State Cabinet for Health and Family Services. The program incorporates education groups, individual counseling, group counseling, peer support and medical treatment of substance use and mental health disorders. Although the clinic is revenue- generating, 95% of services provided are supported by grants. In fall 2020, the clinic was transitioned to UKHC to advance services and strengthen operations under the "umbrella" of UKHC's Behavioral Health Initiative. Gifts to the CON and interest generated by endowments (market value of $6,368,907) are used primarily to support student scholarships. In addition, two endowed chairs and five endowed professorships are supported by donors. Another source of revenue is the Office of Professional Development for continuing education operated within the CON. The program, which is fiscally self-sustaining and nationally accredited with distinction, provides an important service to the Commonwealth and beyond. Another source of support for College is through the University of Kentucky 21 st Century "Kentucky Can" Cap ital Campaign that was launched in 2018 with a $2.1 billion fund-raising effort. The College of Nursing goal to raise $12 million is currently at $10 million for addressing priority areas to support student scholarships, endowed professorships, research, and academic programming. Although the pandemic has slowed fund -raising efforts significantly, top funded areas are currently for student scholarships and programm ing such as building a Culture of Practices for Resiliency (CPR) to address mental health and wellness for students, faculty, and staff. Each spring, the UK general fund and UKHC budget requests are developed by the Dean and the Associate Dean of Executive Administrative Affairs and Finance and presented to the Provost, the UK Executive Vice President for Finance and Administration and the UK Executive Vice President for Health Affairs (EVPHA). The budget process includes justific ation for current funding as well as requests for new initiatives, including one - time expenses such as building renovations and major equipment purchases. If the CON has general funds remaining at the end of the fiscal year, a request is submitted to the Provost to carry forward a portion of the funds into the next fiscal year, a process which supports the CON's need to fund one- time initiatives. In Fall of 2017, the Provost engaged with UKHC EVPHA for increased funding support for the CON through an at -risk funding performance agreement. Annually, goals are reviewed and/or updated with UKHC nursing leadership and the CON Dean to determine mutually agreed upon metrics and funding amounts. Currently the performance measures evaluated focus on BSN (tradition al and accelerated) outcomes and include: (1) number of Kentucky residents admitted; (2) number of CON graduates hired at UKHC; (3) diversity of students admitted; 15 and (4) UKHC workforce readiness projects such as implementing holistic admissions and expanding SNAP (student nursing academic practicum) for year -round experiences. Once approved by the Board of Trustees, the budget is sent to the Kentucky Council for Post -Secondary Education (K CPE). The Council is responsible for submitting the proposal for all post -secondary programs to the Governor. The Kentucky Legislature determines state appropriations during their annual session. Faculty provide input to the budget process through a variet y of mechanisms, including Faculty Council (elected faculty for Faculty Organization leadership), the Associate Dean to whom faculty report needs specific to their programmatic responsibilities and activities, and faculty forums organized by the Dean's off ice to address specific budget issues. The CON faces the same challenges as other programs of nursing in competing with higher salaries offered in the clinical arena. CON faculty salaries compare favorably to AACN benchmarks for Schools of Nursing in Academic Health Science Centers and are reviewed annually for possible adjustments. Table IIA-2: CON Means Salaries for Faculty 2019- 2020, shows mean salaries for full -time CON faculty by rank and academic year appointment (10 months) or calendar year appointment (12 months). Also displayed in Table IIA -2 are national data on the mean salaries for academic year appointments and calendar year appointments. A review of the data in the table shows that for most categories, salaries in the CON are higher than the mean salaries reported by AACN. The exception is for the academic year salary at the instructor level for those with a doctorate. This may be reflective of salary compression, as many have been at UK for several years. All base salaries of CON faculty are reviewed annually and adjusted as state funding supports with the exception of high merit and promotions.
