Adequacy of physical resources and clinical sites is reviewed periodically, and resources are modified as needed. Elaboration: Physical space and facilities (e.g., faculty and staff work space, classrooms, meeting areas) are sufficient and configured in ways that enable the program to achieve its mission, goals, and expected outcomes. Equipment and supplies (e.g., com puting, laboratory, and teaching -learning materials) are sufficient to achieve the program's mission, goals, and expected outcomes. The program is responsible for ensuring adequate physical resources and clinical sites. Clinical sites are sufficient, appropriate, and available to achieve the program's mission, goals, and expected outcomes. A defined process is used to determine currency, availability, accessibility, and adequacy of resources (e.g., clinical simulation, laboratory, computing, supplies, and clinical sites), and modifications are made as appropriate. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Physical resources are adequate and reviewed as needed. Built in 1974, the CON building is approximately 121,000 square feet over six floors. The space occupied by the CON includes faculty and staff offices, teaching laboratories for clinical courses including the Clinical Simulation and Learning Center, the Center for Nursing Research, lounges for faculty, staff and students, and several conference rooms. Clinical sites are sufficient and appropriate to meet the expected outcomes of each program. The CON has available sites at local hospitals, schools, clinics, and public health agencies, among others. The programs are utilizing simulated learning to augment some of the scenario's students may not be exposed to in the clinical setting. Office Space and Common Areas Considerable strategic investments have been made by the CON and the University for refurbishing and renovations over the past 15 years. Specifically, over the past seven years, faculty and staff offices have been renovated, which included painting and the addition of ergonomically designed furniture. The public areas of the CON have been painted and floor tile has been replaced as needed. Other investments include replacing all stair 17 treads and signage in the stairwells, relocating two large research teams due to limited space in the CON and to accommodate the rapid growth in funded programs. Both teams (the BREATHE team was relocated to a 5,704 square feet location and the RICH Heart team was relocated to a 3,910 square feet location) are located within six miles of the CON in spaces that are leased through the University and meet University guidelines. The offices were furnished, and faculty members and their research staff were moved to the off-site locations. relocating two research teams off campus . Updating the Hall of Fame lobby area, replac ing tile floors on the first floor, replacing lighting on each floor and completing a major renovation for the Office of Nursing Research (4,165 square feet on the 5th floor). This area now has more efficient space for research assistants, research staff, research pre- and post -support, and the Associate Dean for Research. There is a deli and coffee shop adjacent to the CON. Key cards are required for entry into the student lounges and the CON building after hours. The bathrooms on the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, and 5th floors have all been renovated. Both 3rd floor bathrooms are designated with signage as gender inclusive. During the 2016- 17 academic year, the CON participated in the larger, campus -wide strategic goal to develop "Work -Life Balance." One of the most tangible results of our efforts was the creation of the Cultivating Practices for Resilience (CPR) room, which opened October 2017. This space is located on the 6th floor with approximately 400 square feet of space. Located in a corner of the building with full -length windows that overlook the campus, the CPR room is dedicated to helping alleviate stress and anxiety in faculty, staff, and students. The College provided supplies for the practice of yoga, a large monitor, rocking chairs, a massage chair, and a cascading water fountain for creation of a relaxing ambiance. This was partially supported through private donors with interest in building healthy working and learning environments. A healthy workplace is critical to our well-being as well as those we serve. There have been continuous improvements in the CON building as funding allowed. During summer 2018, UK Facilities upgraded the large Auditorium 201, which seats 295 students. This renovation included lighting, ceiling, painting, new flooring, and an upgrade of the sound system. The hallway on first floor was also tiled and new lighting ceiling grid s were installed. In fall 2019, the fourth and fifth floor corridors where faculty offices are located were painted, and ceiling tiles and grids were replaced. Lighting on each floor (1, 2, 4 and 5) was updated to LED. Conference Rooms The CON has four co nference rooms, one on the third floor, one in the Center for Nursing Research on the 5th floor, and two on the second floor, which are available for meetings. The conference rooms can be used by CON faculty as well as those outside of the CON and are distance -learning capable. The conference rooms are scheduled by the Dean's administrative staff. Additional meeting rooms may be scheduled through Central Scheduling in any of the adjacent buildings for both small and large meetings. Classrooms Classrooms include space assigned to the CON within the CON building as well as access to centrally managed classrooms and lecture halls, technology, and other equipment. Each classroom is equipped with audiovisual equipment and computers for internet access. Additionally, there are eight centrally supported classrooms at the University that are distance -learning capable and located on campus. UK Facilities manages improvements to the classrooms and most major renovations are done on a rotating basis. The College of Nursing has a mid-size lecture hall (135 seats) and a large- size lecture hall (295 seats) that was renovated during summer 2018. Clinical Simulation and Learning Center The Clinical Simulation and Learning Center (CSLC) consists of 10,000 s quare feet of space designated for experiential learning. Contained in the CSLC are simulated hospital rooms, exam rooms, and other treatment areas that incorporate audiovisual equipment that help both undergraduate and graduate students receive hands - on feedback through video recordings. These areas are designed to provide students with a realistic learning environment to maintain environmental fidelity. In the CSLC, there are high-fidelity simulators and task trainers that are specifically designed to assist students and learners in applying skills and knowledge needed by healthcare professionals. The CSLC is provisionally accredited by the Society for Simulation in Healthcare. The CSLC self -study has been subm itted for review to become fully accredited. In spring of 2017, the CON Clinical Simulation and Learning Center (CSLC) was renovated to include a Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. Through a 18 partnership with UKHC, and as part of the design process for a new Neo natal Intensive Care Unit, the Kentucky Children's Hospital completed a replica of a neonatal intensive care hospital room in the CSLC. Conveniently located (4th floor of the CON), healthcare providers as well as nursing students are now able to experience care of the neonate more fully. Computer Resources All full- time faculty and staff are provided computers. Faculty members are given a choice of a desktop or laptop computer. Wireless access is available throughout the CON building and across campus. The CON has five servers housed at UKHC's server farm and one server in-house. UK provides site licenses for Microsoft Office, Microsoft Operating System, Adobe products, and Forefront antivirus, among many others. The University invested in additional comput er space on the 6 th floor of the CON. This renovation created a 42- seat computer classroom and upgraded the data technology infrastructure to optimize the use of the computer classroom for undergraduate and graduate students. For online course management, Canvas® by Instructure is used. UK holds a site license for SAS and SPSS that is available for faculty, staff, and students. Individual or group licenses are purchased for other software as needed by faculty, staff, and students. Students have access to computers in the UK computer lab located on the 6th floor of the CON building. In addition, five computers and a printer are available to graduate students in the 5th floor graduate study area. Clinical Facilities The CON has access and contracts to use all of the hospitals in Fayette County, including Albert B. Chandler, UK Good Samaritan, Eastern State Hospital, CHI Saint Joseph Health, CHI Saint Joseph East, and Baptist Health Lexington, the Phyllis D. Corbitt Community Health Center f or student clinical placements, to name a few. Clinical space is competitive as there are several nursing programs in the area. The Assistant Dean for the Undergraduate Program participates in Bluegrass Planning, which consists of representatives from the area nursing programs, to negotiate the type and number of clinical sites needed each semester. The Advanced Practice Registered Nurse students are placed with a preceptor for each of the clinical courses. Obtaining a preceptor for each student is a very competitive process, as there are several nurse practitioner programs in the area as well as students attending online programs. The DNP track coordinators are responsible for finding clinical placements for their students. While this is a laborious process, the CON has been able to assure clinical placements for all students each semester. Norton- Healthcare Facilities During 2014 and 2015, the CON -Norton Health Care (NHC) academic -practice partnership was offered in the NHC Institute for Nursing dedicated space located in an office tower adjacent to the NHC Audubon Hospital in Louisville, Kentucky. Space was more than adequate for the first two CON -NHC DNP student cohort groups, each with an enrollment of 20 students. The space was equipped with three large classrooms, a computer room with approximately 15 computers, and six examination rooms (some set up as office examination rooms and others with hospital equipment). Class rooms were configured with audio and video capabilities, laptop connections and Internet access. Faculty and staff offices with computer set -up were available as well as an open area with a printer and supplies. During 2016, NHC began renovation of a four -story office building to include a Learning Center and NHC office space. In January 2017, the NHC Learning Center opened for student, faculty, and staff occupancy. Among the three NHC levels, the new office space added 15,300 square feet of classroom and employee learning space, approximately doubling the previous amount of space NHC had devoted to education. The second floor NHC Learning Center, located at 9500 Ormsby Station Road, Louisville, is equipped with eight classrooms with seating capacity from 20 to 126 people. All the classrooms have wireless Internet access and availability for personal laptop connections. Some have flat screen monitors, and some have large screen projection for video conferencing. One classroom serves as a computer lab with 24 personal computers, along with a speaker lectern and flat screen monitor. The CON -NHC nursing hub includes a reception area and office space for faculty and staff. 19 II-C. Academic support services are sufficient to meet program an d student needs and are evaluated on a regular basis. Elaboration: Academic support services, which may include library, technology, distance education support, research support, and admission and advising services, foster achievement of program outcomes. A defined process is used for regular review of academic support services, and improvements are made as appropriate. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Noted for top academic rankings (consistent 97% NCLEX average, largest number of BSN graduates in Kentucky, NLN Center for Nursing Education Excellence, DNP ranked #26 in U.S. News and World Report, top 10 NIH Nursing Research among publics, and top 10 PhD programs by U.S. National Research Council) the CON has sufficient academic support services for students and faculty to achieve the mission, goals and expected program outcomes. Library Support There are more than one dozen facilities that comprise the UK Libraries. With the largest book endowment of all public universities in the United States, UK libraries are among the world's leading research libraries. The libraries' broad scope of advanced technology offers students, faculty, and staff access to cu rrent information online in addition to printed resources. UK's main library, the William T. Young University Library, houses 1.2 million volumes for the social sciences, humanities, and life sciences. The library includes 57 group study and conference rooms as well as study areas that seat 350. There are 350 personal computers available for patrons and staff and 3,000 network ports throughout the library to support faculty and student computing needs. The library system contains 5,432,663 volumes; of those, 2,165,118 are e -books. The total UK library system subscribes to 885,019 journals/serial subscriptions including 148,639 e-journals. Faculty, staff, and students have access to 435 licensed databases. Free interlibrary loan and document delivery services as well as online literature searches, reference staff consultations and library instruction sessions are available to faculty, staff, and students. UK Libraries uses the SpringShare suite of programs to produce LibGuides on a variety of topics. The Medical Center Library is conveniently located across the street from the CON. There are 16 computers in the Medical Center Library teaching/learning center and 20 computers in the library proper, available for patron use. The lower level of the library was renovated and opened in the fall of 2018. It was designed to provide open, collaborative space and quiet study areas. Endnote X5 for Windows is available via the Medical Center website for downloading by all students, faculty, and staff. Some of the many other resources available to students and faculty include: CINAHL, PubMed, Web of Science, Scopus, Cochrane Library, BoardVitals N CLEX-RN test bank, PsycINFO, and Health and Psychosocial Instruments (HaPI). Research workshops and individual trainings on the use of these and other resources are offered throughout each semester. The Medical Center Library designated a Research and Edu cation librarian as the liaison for the CON faculty and students. She is the first point of contact for information about library policies, procedures, and services, and provides specialized research consultations, teaches classes to support research using library resources, and provides collection management assistance. She maintains a College of Nursing Library Resources guide which provides quick access to resources and services. Her office is conveniently located on the 6th floor of the CON building. On an annual basis during budget planning for the next fiscal year, the librarian polls the faculty to determine if new library resources are needed. Faculty can request resources during other times of the year, budget permitting. The CON librarian provides informational support as an embedded librarian in two Canvas® courses: NUR 200 (Foundations for Professional Nursing) and NUR 453 (Nursing Capstone). An introductory message with links to resources and services is provided. Students can ask questions within the Canvas® site. Research informational support is given via email, phone, face to face or via video conferencing software. The CON librarian provides instructional support for three undergraduate courses: NUR 310 (Evidence Based Nursing Practice), NUR 328 (Research for Evidence Based Nursing Practice), and NUR 450 (Impact of 20 Evidence Based Practice in Nursing). Search strategy lectures demonstrating multiple databases are recorded and made available to the students in Canvas®. In NUR 310 (Evidence Based Nursing Practice) , the students view the recording as a pre-assignment and then a follow -up, hands -on class is scheduled with the librarian. The students are given a post assignment during the hands -on class and the librarian gives personalized assistance to the students while they search for literature. In NUR 328 (Research for Evidence Based Nursing Practice), and NUR 450 Impac t of Evidence Based Practice in Nursing) , the course instructors have embedded quizzes at different portions during the searching lecture to reinforce student learning. For example, in the DNP program she is included as an instructor in NUR 916 (Program Pl anning & Evaluation for Improvement in Practice and Health Outcomes) and in NUR 909 (Proposal Development), where she assists students refine the search terms to obtain the best evidence related to their DNP Project. At the beginning of each semester, the course instructor and the CON librarian discuss the content and format of the classes. Updates to the assignment and content of the recorded lectures are made based on student feedback and course instructor/librarian observations. UK Libraries evaluate service quality by administering the national Association of Research Libraries (ARL) LibQUAL+® survey every four years and benchmarks with the ARL mean scores. In 2020, UK Libraries' scores were equal to or above the ARL service quality mean and have increased over our 2017 scores for both undergraduate and graduate students, for library collections, electronic resources, and facilities. A locally - developed Library User Satisfaction S urvey, conducted every four years, measures user satisfaction in individual campus libraries and will next be implemented in 2021. Improvements made as a result of these evaluations included the following: library resources were made more accessible by pur chasing additional resources in electronic form; hours of service were extended to 24/5 in the Young Library; a graduate student study space was created in the Young Library; and more quiet study space was designated within the Young Library. The Education, Medical Center and Law Libraries have each been extensively renovated within the past two years. The CON has used classroom management software since its introduction at UK and advocated for its purchase and adoption. In the Undergraduate program, utili zation of Canvas® (learning management software) is on an individual course basis. Undergraduate faculty use technologies such as Turning Point's ® audience response system and Echo 360 lecture capture to aid students in learning course material. Canvas® is utilized in all of the courses in the MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs as well as Echo 360 lecture capture and zoom. The CON Information Technology group (CONIT) consists of one Director, one server administrator, and one desktop support technician. The CONIT Director works closely with the Dean and Associate Dean for Executive Administrative Operations & Finance in the CON. The CONIT Director helps with the development of IT policy and ensures service level agreements with in the CON are met as well as directing the priorities of the group. The Director also works as the CON liaison with the Campus IT group, and the Medical Center IT group. The south campus office of Audio Visual (AV) Services, a part of UK Instructional Technology, is located in the CON. Its mission is to provide support for the use of multimedia technology to meet the education, research, and service missions of UK. AV supports audio taping from single digital audio recording to multiple microphones set up for round table discussions. Voice recording for video or presentation narration is also provided. AV equipment is available for check out free of charge to all colleges. The following is a brief summary of computer resources within the C ollege of Nursing: CON IT Staff support of all full -time faculty and staff within the CON regarding computer issues; Faculty members are given a choice of a desktop computer or a laptop; The CON has two servers housed at the Medical Center's data center; Wireless and ethernet access is available throughout the building and across campus; and UK provides licensed Microsoft Office, Operating System, Adobe, and Forefront antivirus software, among many others, to all faculty, staff, and students All computer resources being utilized by the CON are to be compliant with the University of Kentucky Enterprise and Medical Center Administrative Regulation 10:1 through 10:5 . The policy applies to users of University information technology resources irrespective of whether those resources are accessed from on - 21 campus or off -campus location. The policy applies to all University information technology resources including: Data and other files, including electronic mail and voice mail, stored in individual computer accounts on University -owned centrally maintained systems; Data and other files, including electronic mail or voice mail stored on departmentally maintained systems; Data and other files, including electronic mail and voice mail, stored in individual computer accounts on systems managed by the University on behalf of affiliated organizations; Data and other files, including electronic mail or voice mail, stored on perso nally-owned devices on University property (e.g., residence hall rooms); Data and other files, including electronic mail or voice mail stored on University -owned systems assigned to a specific individual for use in support of job functions; and Telecommuni cations (voice or data) traffic from, to, or between any devices described above. Distance Learning In spring 2015, the CON completed an external review on the operations of the Office of Instructional Technology. It was recommended to restructure staffing so that the instructional technologist/designer works more closely with faculty on the use of technology in instruction as well as online course design. The instructional design team now reports to the Assistant Dean of Academic Operations to predominantly support all distance learning modalities. The technologist also aids with all aspects of Canvas®® management and other online technologies such as: Echo 360® personal and lecture capture software, Camtasia®, instructional videos and PowerPoint voiceovers, the use of Skype®, Zoom® for classroom conferencing, the use of Turning Point's® audience response system, Examsoft® testing software, and websites or Share Point® sites developed for academic use, as well as Digication for ePortfolio® creation in the DNP program. The instructional technologist/designer works closely with eLearning, CELT, College of Nursing IT, ITS, AV Services, so faculty receive the support they need for optimizing student learning. In fall 2016, the CON converted its RN-BSN program to a 100% online program. Undergraduate faculty are in the process of identifying BSN (traditional and ABSN) courses that may be converted for online lea rning as well. An immersion delivery model for the DNP Program was implemented in 2019. DNP students attend classes on campus at the beginning and end of each semester to complete course requirements, which are outside the online courses. The immersion mod el students meet for three blocked days at the beginning of the semester, and two blocked days at the end of the semester. The CON benefits from several faculty members who are certified online educators including one that is designated as Director of Onl ine Innovation. Currently there are 19 full -time and seven part -time faculty who are certified as online educators. Detailed online support for students in the use of Canvas®® is available at http://www.uky.edu/Canvas®/ . This includes information on such topics as: how to get started, how to get online training, logging in, system requirements, completing graded work, grades, tools, and troubleshooting, among others. Online information/support for instructors is available at the same link, http://www.uky.edu/Canvas®/ . Faculty members also obtain support for the use of Canvas®® from the staff of the Center for Enh ancement of Learning and Teaching (CELT), which is discussed in a section below. Integrated faculty and student support services for distance learning include Distance Learning Library Services , information about online programs and resources, is available at http://www.uky.edu/ukonline/ . The UK Online office has developed an Online Teaching Toolkit , avail able to help design, develop and support learning for online teaching. There is an Information Technology Services Grant Program for faculty to apply for funding to develop Distance Learning courses or programs. In addition, since its inception in 2015 several faculty members have benefitted from CELT grants to advance online innovation. Documentation available in the Virtual Resource Room. Clinical Simulation and Learning Center The Assistant Dean of Academic Operations provides administrative oversight o f the CSLC function, including overall evaluation of the faculty and staff. The CSLC Director is a certified healthcare simulation educator and has a 1.0 FTE faculty Lecturer position. The CSLC Director maintains oversight of both the daily academic activi ties and operations. This includes personnel assignments, simulators, rooms, equipment, manikins, and supplies. The CSLC Director is responsible for determining the simulation schedule for the 22 Undergraduate program along with the simulation instructional support specialist. The scheduling for simulation used in the Graduate program is based on the needs of the individual courses following the Policy and Procedure for Scheduling. The simulation instructional support specialist (1.0 FTE) is responsible for managing the daily simulation schedule, assisting the students in arranging group times that do not conflict with their schedule, and overall business operations of the CSLC. The simulation lab coordinator senior (1.0 FTE) is responsible for maintenance and inventory of the equipment, manikins, and supplies. They ensure that all supplies, equipment, paperwork and moulage (the art of applying moc k injuries for the purpose of training medical and military personnel) are available and ready to use in each simulation room. They maintain and troubleshoot all technology, including hardware and software; assist with the facilitation of simulation throug h the use of technology; and ensure that simulation specialists and other faculty using the CSLC have what they need and that it is operational. In addition, the simulation lab coordinator senior assists the simulation instructional support specialist with operation of the CSLC as needed. All courses with simulation are held to the International Nursing Association for Clinical Simulation & Learning (INACSL) Standards of Best Practice: Simulation. The CSLC Director ensures that the appropria te simulation modality is chosen to best meet the objectives of the SCE. All simulation activities need final approval by the CSLC Director, who is a Certified Healthcare Simulation Educator (CHSE), two weeks prior to the event to ensure alignment with simulation standards and the training mission of the CSLC. Objectives need to be sent when scheduled. The simulations are evaluated in several ways and are under constant revision based on student and faculty feedback. Students complete an evaluation following each simulated clinical experience (SCE). The design of the SCE, facilitator, and perceived challenges are included in the evaluation using modified versions of the National League for Nursing Educational Practices Questionnaire, Student Satisfaction and Self -Confidence in Learning, and Simulation Design Scale. Table II C-1: CLSC Student Satisfaction: Spring 2020 reflects the results of the 2020 Student Satisfaction survey. The students will receive "meets expectation," "needs improvement," or "unsatisfactory" based on their performance during the SCE. The students also receive written formative feedback, in addition to debriefing, based on any areas where they need improvement or are unsatisfactory. Most of the "needs improvement" for the final SCE were in the category of prioritizat ion. All students were successful in their clinical experience. Research Support The Office of Nursing Research (ONR) offers support services for research and scholarly activities for faculty and students in the recently renovated 4,165 square feet space on the 5th floor of the CON. A recent reorganization of CON leadership expanded the responsibilities of the Associate Dean of Research to include PhD Faculty Affairs and added an Assistant Dean of PhD Program and Scholarly Affairs as well as a Counci l for the Advancement of Student Scholarly Affairs. 23 Available ONR resources and services include assistance in locating funding sources; preparing research proposals; statistical, research design and sampling design; survey development; psychometric consultation; and manuscript and poster preparation and editing. The Associate Dean for Research oversees the ONR's staff, which includes the following full- time staff members: an administrative coordinator, a grants facilitator, a CON grants officer, an epidemiologist/survey research specialist/data manager and analyst and two doctorally -prepared statisticians. A PhD-prepared statistician, who is a tenured faculty member, also provides statistical consultation and expertise in research and sampling designs. Space is also allocated in this area for funded researchers and undergraduate research interns to work with their mentors . The ONR has a computer in each of the 25 workstations, and all are linked to two printers in that area. Computers are equipped with Microsoft Office® and statistical packages. Atlas.ti® is available for faculty and students conducting qualitative research. The CON uses incentive funds received from indirect costs on extramural grants to support the research productivity of faculty and students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Support for travel to present at state, regional, national, and international conferences is available from the Office of Nursing Research. Poster printing is also paid for from incentive funds. Two other recent examples of incentive funds support included hosting two internationally renowned nurse scientists to consult with faculty on their individual research areas and with faculty research teams, and 18 faculty members who attended an all -day workshop offered on campus by a company called Grantwriters' Seminars and Workshops, LLC to support faculty and student research. UK's Office of the Vice President for Research recently changed its fun ding model to allocate funds directly to Colleges. Although special RFPs may be called, colleges are expected to manage a variety of faculty research support mechanisms, such as start -up funds for new Regular Title Series faculty, bridge funding and facult y research support grants. The Vice President encourages interdisciplinary collaboration by allocating a larger proportion of the indirect costs (16% vs. 10%) for incentive funds when interdisciplinary extramural proposals are funded. To incentivize facult y, the Wethington Awards have been offered to CON faculty who bring in part of their salary on grants. For the past five years, individual faculty with grant salary support received 10% of the amount of salary they personally covered by grants as an incent ive award in May of each year. Admission and Advising Services The CON Office of Student Services (Student Services) facilitates the recruitment, application, and matriculation of undergraduate and graduate nursing students. Six FTE provide support to the students and programs, including: one FTE Assistant Dean of Stu dents, one FTE recruitment coordinator, three FTE undergraduate advisors, one FTE graduate student services officer and one FTE admissions coordinator. In collaboration with faculty and the Associate Deans, members of Student Services develop recruitment plans for all academic programs, provide information to prospective applicants, represent the CON at recruitment/career opportunity events, provide pre-admission counseling, support the admissions process for all academic programs, facilitate student registration and credentials verification, coordinate health and safety compliance, support student organizations, career plan development, and pinning and hooding ceremonies, provide support for enrolled students, plan commenc ement activities, administer the school's scholarship distribution, and maintain all student -related data. Pre-nursing students are admitted to the CON and are advised by professional academic advisors. Support procedures are in place for early intervention for students who are below a passing grade in any nursing course. A collaborative process involving the student, the student's advisor, and course faculty is in place. At the graduate level, students a re assigned a faculty advisor as they enter the program. The average number of advisees per academic advisor in the undergraduate program in 2020 was 255:1. The ratio of advisees per faculty in the MSN program is 5:1. The DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate students and faculty are combined as the same faculty advise both groups and advisees per faculty range from 1 -20. The variability is due to the demands on faculty resources, DOE, and faculty responsibilities througho ut the year. The University academic alert system was created to ensure that students have the academic assistance they need, right when they need it. Faculty and staff can submit an alert about academic concerns for example if a student has missed classes or is performing poorly. The alert is sent to their academic advisor and the student will receive notification that an alert has been submitted. Other Support Services and Enrichment Opportunities for Students The CON has a writing specialist, who conducts a diagnostic writing assessment on all DNP students during the first or second semester of enrollment. The writing specialist provides students with information on such 24 topics as critical thinking, paragraph development, writing a literature review, and writing for publication. Working closely with the UK Medical Center Library liaison to schedule classes in EndNote, a software program designed to help writers manage their reference citations, is also provided. Other services provided include on - site consultation with undergraduate and graduate students as well as via virtual meetings, faculty assistance with improving writing and presentation skills and online video tutorials for writing guidance for students, UKHC nurses and faculty. Support for Undergraduate Students The University's Living Learning Community/Living Learning Program (LLP) established in collaboration with Residence Life Staff, the Interprofessional Residential Healthcare College (IHRC) student dormitory which opened in 2014 to serve undergraduate students participating in the program. Interprofessional Residential Healthcare College is a high -impact, living- learning program designed for students who have a passion for healthcare and interdisciplinary learning. It is an active collaboration among nine colleges on campus and op en to any major. IHRC members can expect to be immersed in a living- learning experience that combines a host of curricular and co -curricular initiatives with a network of faculty and staff dedicated to interprofessional healthcare and student success. Nine IHRC UK partner colleges include: College of Dentistry, College of Health Sciences, College of Medicine, College of Nursing, College of Pharmacy, College of Public Health, College of Social Work, College of Communication & Information, and the College of Agriculture, Food & Environment (Department of Dietetics and Nutrition). Peer tutoring is offered four times each semester for Anatomy and Physiology and Chemistry through this program. NUR 101(Academic Orientation and Introduction to Nursing) provides a University orientation for nursing students. It also teaches study skills and provides students with an introduction to the profession. 2019- 2020 IHRC LLP Academic Year in Review cumulative GPA: 3.53 2020 retention rate: 95.8% Nursing Students: 41 students registered as Pre- nursing or Nursing students Co-Curricular Programming: The IHRC executed 21 of our signature "iRock" co-curricular programs during Fall 2019 and 18 during Spring 2020. Program Satisfaction: o 97% (N = 164) of IHRC students agreed or strongly agreed: "My experience a UK this semester has been positive." o 96% (N = 164) of IHRC students agreed or strongly agreed: "I feel like I belong within my LLP." o 92% (N = 164) of IHRC students agreed or strongly agreed: "My IHRC Peer Mentor has had a positive impact on my experience." o 93% (N = 164) of IHRC students agreed or strongly agreed: "My LLP has had a positive impact on my academics at UK." o 93% (N = 164) of IHRC students agreed or strongly agreed: "If I could start the semester over, I would still choose to be in my LLP." iCATS Student Satisfaction - AY 2016/2017 to 2019/2020 Approximately 250 undergraduate nursing students (Traditional BSN and Accelerated BSN) engage annually in a required UK Center for Interprofessional Health Education (CIHE) core interprofessional curriculum entitled iCATS (Interprofessional Collaboration and Team Skills) for all first/second year students (approximately 1000) . Students focus on foundational patient and team communication skills. Small interprofessional (IP) teams (10-12 students) facilitated by health profession faculty meet to learn with, from, and about one another. Two half- day sessions occur early in the spring semester and include a variety of team activities to practice new skills, including a simulation with a standardized patient about disclosure of a medical error. Evaluation of the iCATS curriculum occurs each spring seme ster by the CIHE Academic Leadership Team (academic deans from each health profession college), CIHE fellows/associates, individual college councils for IPE and the CIHE advisory board. As reflected in the below table, previous to the current curriculum of two half -day sessions, there were six sessions that were deemed to be too long (student feedback) and taxing (faculty feedback) and resulted in outcomes in the 2 -3 range on a 1 -5 scale. The new curriculum gives students an opportunity to work in small IP faculty facilitated interprofessional teams to understand and practice the PEEER (Plain Language, Engagement, Empathy, Empowerment, Respect) communication model and develop a transition of care plan for a simulated patient (day one). On day two, these same teams solidify these skills, en vivo, by participating in a team -based 25 simulation with a standardized patent. As a result, student satisfaction increased significantly without compromising student learning outcomes as reflected in Table II B -2 Selected iC ATS Outcomes. Table IIC -2 Selected iCATS Outcomes Question Year CSD PAS PT COD COM CON COP CPH CSW Overall Overall, the iCATS experience I was successfully able to interact with other students outside my own profession. class meetings was appropriate. 2016/17 iCATS experience has provided me with a foundational understanding of interprofessional education and team - based collaboration in health 4.47 There was an appropriate variety of learning formats for the activities (pre-work reading, class discussion, partner/small group work, videos, online discussion board, Science & Disorders; PAS = Physician Assistant Studies; PT = Physical Therapy: COD= Dentistry; - Public Health; CSW = Social Work First-Aid Friday Peer Study Groups (FAF) is a study hall resource for undergraduate nursing students, offered Fridays from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., to provide tutoring and skills practice opportunities outside lab/classroom times. Upper- class student tutors are available to assist study groups with nursing content questions. Graduate nursing students provide skill support. Nursing students who fail any NUR course are at risk and are referred to FAF as part of their plan for success. Attendance is monitored and in some cases the correlation can be made between participation at FAF and a successful outcome the second time through a course. Data indicate that students in the first two semesters of the sophomore year continue to be the most frequent users of FAF. Qualitative reports highlight these students find this experience to be a relaxed and inviting where they can work in focused study groups, practice NCLEX- type questions on the computer software, and practice nursing skills. They further describe becoming competent in performing many nursing skills specific to the nursing lab (e.g., sterile dressing changes, medication injections, vital signs). The Dose, published three times/semester, is an emailed newsletter managed by the academic program specialist that focuses on information specifically for undergraduate nursing students. It continues to be a 26 consistent way to communicate with undergraduate students and includes scholarship and job opportunities, community service, and CON student and faculty updates, while also highlighting student's successes. Qualitative assessments of both students and faculty alike describe the Dose as a we lcoming and informative student - centered CON publication. II-D. The chief nurse administrator of the nursing unit: is a registered nurse (RN); holds a graduate degree in nursing; holds a doctoral degree if the nursing unit offers a graduate program in nursing; is vested with the administrative authority to accomplish the mission, goals, and expected program outcomes; and provides effective leadership to the nursing unit in achieving its mission, goals, and expected program outcomes. Elaboration: The administrative authority of the chief nurse administrator is comparable to that of chief administrators of similar units in the institution. He or she consults, as appropriate, with faculty and other communities of interest to make decisions to accomplish the mission, goals, and expected program outcomes. The chief nurse administrator is an effective leader of the nursing unit. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Janie Heath, PhD, appointed Dean and Warwick Professor of Nursing for the UK College of Nursing in August of 2014 (Dr. Patricia Howard served as Interim Dean from December 2012 until August 2014) and has demonstrated to be well qualified to lead the College in its pursuit of its mission and strategic goals. Dr. Heath was previously the Chief Academic Officer for the University of Virginia School of Nursing. She also held aca demic nursing leadership positions and taught at the Medical College of Georgia in Augusta, Georgia, Georgetown University in Washington, DC and the University of South Carolina in Columbia, South Carolina. Dr. Heath has been awarded over $12 million for academic and/or research initiatives, generated over 160 publications and presentations, and provided leadership for numerous national and regional organizations to build a culture of health and strengthen the nursing workforce, including Board of Directors for the American Association of Critical Care Nurses. Dr. Heath earned her associate and bachelor's degree in nursing from Cameron University in Lawton, Oklahoma, an MS in nursing from the University of Oklahoma, a post-masters Adult Nurse Practitioner certificate from the University of South Carolina, a PhD from George Mason University in Fairfax, Virginia and a Management and Leadership in Education Program certificate from Harvard Graduate Institute of Higher Education. Dr. Heath has served in a faculty role since 1994 and has a sustained program of funded research in tobacco control. She was inducted as a Fellow of the American Academy of Nursing in 2007, a Fellow of the National Academies of Practice in 2014 and a Fellow of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners in 2017. The University of Oklahoma recently honored her as the inaugural Distinguished College of Nursing Alumni. Dr. Heath is also recognized for her national leadership with the American Association of Co lleges of Nursing, the American Academy of Nursing and her board service on the Friends of National Institute for Nursing Research as well as her state service as President of the Kentucky Nursing Action Coalition. Dr. Heath's teaching and scholarship at UK have focused on tobacco control, nursing professionalism, care of acute and critically care populations and academic clinical partnerships. She is actively engaged in teaching and mentoring undergraduate and graduate students specifically addressing topics/lectures related to executive and clinical leadership, cultivating practices for resilience, and student mental health and wellness. She is the senior health profession college dean at the University and is known for her high level of engagement and co nnection with students. As Chair of the Board of Directors for the UK Center for Interprofessional Health Education (CIHE) she has also influenced learning experiences for 1,600 students across 10 colleges at the University through 12 CIHE program offerings facilitated by 275 faculty participants. The colleges at the University of Kentucky function with a high degree of autonomy and Dr. Heath has the same budgetary, decision -making and evaluation authority as other deans. She reports directly to the provost 27 of the University and has a dotted line to the Executive Vice President of Health Affairs at UK HealthCare. As CON Dean, Dr. Heath consults with faculty and students routinely to make decisions about strategic initiatives/goals/challenges. She convenes bi- weekly meetings of her Dea ns Council, Faculty Council, and monthly Faculty Organization meetings. She also seeks input from individual tenured/non- tenured faculty, on teaching, scholarship/research, practice, and service innovations. In addition, she meets twice a year with the Dean's Advisory Board and the Dean's Diversity Board, a group of donors, business and healthcare executives, community partners, alumni, and faculty, to seek guidance for advancing CON initiatives. Recently the faculty surprised Dr. Heath with an award for her leadership during a triple crisis with state budget cuts, pandemic, and social/racial injustice. Dean Heath recognizes the many challenges facing academic nurse leaders today and has enthusiastically embraced opportunities to advocate for and garner resources to advance CON strategic initiatives to advance academic programming, research, practice, and service. She has been recognized by the University for her active engagement with the UK Capital Campaign, advancement, and retention of black faculty, increased financial support from UKHC, support of military students, rural health outreach and University wide collaborative research. Dr. Heath's signature mark for effective leadership ov er the past 7 years is building a culture that promotes healthy working and learning environments for students, faculty, and staff to reach their full potential. II-E. Faculty are: sufficient in number to accomplish the mission, goals, and expected program outcomes; academically prepared for the areas in which they teach; and experientially prepared for the areas in which they teach. Elaboration: The faculty (full- time, part -time, adjunct, tenured, non -tenured, or other) for each degree and post -graduate APRN certificate program are sufficient in number and qualifications to achieve the mission, goals, and expected program outcomes. The program defines faculty workloads. Faculty -to- student ratios provide adequate supervision and evaluation and meet or exceed the requirements of regulatory agencies and professional nursing standards and guidelines. Faculty are academically prepared for the areas in which they teach. Academic preparation of faculty includes degree specialization, sp ecialty coursework, or other preparation sufficient to address the major concepts included in courses they teach. Faculty teaching in the nursing program have a graduate degree. The program provides a justification for the use of any faculty who do not hav e a graduate degree. Faculty who are nurses hold current RN licensure. Faculty teaching in clinical/practicum courses are experienced in the clinical area of the course and maintain clinical expertise. Clinical expertise may be maintained through clinical practice or other avenues. Faculty teaching in advanced practice clinical courses meet certification and practice requirements as specified by the relevant regulatory and specialty bodies. Advanced practice nursing tracks are directly overseen by faculty who are nationally certified in that same population -focused area of practice in roles for which national certification is available. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Although stretched with recent rapid growth in undergraduate and graduate nursing programs, faculty are accomplishing the mission, goals, and expected student and faculty outcomes and are academically and experientially prepared for the areas in which they teach (Table IIE- 1: Faculty Qualifications). The CON continues to recruit and retain qualified faculty members and as of December 2020 there are four vacant, approved, tenure- track, full- time position s posted. A testament to the overall quality of faculty are 39 faculty/faculty emeriti are Fellows in national societies/organizations and three have been designated as Living Legends by the American Academy of Nursing. Faculty Academic Preparation Of the 68 full- time faculty, 58 (85%) are doctorally -prepared and the remainder hold the MSN degree, 28 except for the writing specialist who holds an MFA. The Associate and Assistant Deans for the respective programs assign faculty members to teach specified courses based on their academic preparation as well as their clinical and/or research expertise. The numbers and percentage of full-time faculty by rank are: 14 (21%) tenured professors; track research assistant professor; 13 (19%) non -tenure track clinical associate and assistant professors; 2 (3%) instructors; 5 (7%) senior lecturers; and 10 (15%) lecturers. In addition, the CON also draws on the expertise of 75 part -time faculty members, 21 adjunct faculty, and four faculty with joint appointments in the CON - two from the College of Medicine, one from the Colleg e of Public Health, and one from the College of Education. Faculty FTE The FTE faculty required by each program is determined by the Associate Deans based on the number and type of courses and clinical sections needed and the number of students enrolled or anticipated to enroll in the various courses/programs. Some faculty members teach and/or advise across programs. The Faculty Workload Policy Statement for UK is available in the Administrative Regulations . Distribution of Effort (DOE)/workload continues to be the responsibility of the Senior Administrator (Senior Associate Dean, Associate Dean of Undergraduate Faculty & Interprofession al Education Affairs, Associate Dean of MSN and DNP Faculty & Practice Affairs, and Associate Dean for Research) with careful consideration of each faculty member's interests, engagement and responsibilities in the areas of teaching, service/practice, research and scholarship. In general, the process used for assigning DOE includes expecting tenure -track/tenured faculty to teach two courses each semester in addition to meeting service/practice and scholarship commitments. Tenure -track faculty, in their first two years, are allocated lighter teaching loads to support their research trajectory. Full -time, non -tenure track faculty are commonly expected to teach a combination of didactic, clinical and/or laboratory classes each week. Clinical title series faculty are expected to integrate faculty practice (direct care services or indirect care services) one day a week or as negotiated with their Associate Dean. Administrative responsibilities for Assistant Deans and track coordinators are also allocated in the DOE document. Faculty Experiential Preparation All CON faculty, where appropriate, that are nurses hold an unencumbered Registered Nurse (RN) licensure in Kentucky. This is verified online at the Kentucky Board of Nursing (KBN) website each fall semester by staff in the offices of the Dean and Associate Deans for their group of direct reports. Faculty who teach advanced practice clinical courses meet relevant certification and practice requirements of regulatory and specialty bodies. Thirty (44%) of the full- time, graduate faculty hold certifications in their specialt y areas. Of the 68 full- time faculty members, 15 teach in the DNP/Certificate Programs and 36 faculty members teach in the Undergraduate Program (excludes faculty teaching in PhD program). In the DNP/Certificate Programs, 15 (100%) of the full- time faculty hold a doctoral degree. In the Undergraduate Program, 20 (61%) of the full- time faculty hold a doctoral degree. Of the full - and part-time faculty teaching in the Undergraduate Program, 10 are certified in their area of specialty. Two of the master's prepared faculty members are pursuing doctoral degrees. Clinical instructor faculty are selected based on their expertis e. Currently, seven (93%) hold an MSN or higher and five (0.06%) hold a BSN degree. Graduate faculty members teaching in clinical courses are encouraged to maintain an active clinical practice as part of their DOE. This is considered important not only to maintain individual expertise but also to ensure effective role models, update and enrich teaching, and develop quality clinical teaching sites. Clinical practice also provides opportunities to demonst rate innovative nursing practice and serves as a basis for scholarship. Faculty have been encouraged and provided with administrative support to develop innovative relationships with practice settings. Currently, 20 faculty members (29% of full- time faculty) participate in various faculty practice venues (direct billing services and/or indirect care services) as part of their assigned workload, including community clinics, mobile/telemedicine clinics, and acute care settings. In 2016, UKHC established a new process for non -tenure track faculty who are doctorally -prepared to be selected for a Clinical Scholar Appointment to help facilitate nursing scholarship and research. Faculty/Student Ratios Faculty -to-student ratios ensure adequate supervision and evalu ation; they also meet regulatory 29 requirements and professional nursing standards and guidelines. The ratio of undergraduate students to faculty in the clinical setting is no more than 10 students to one faculty member, which is consistent with the guidelin es set forth by the KBN. A 1:8 ratio is maintained in the high acuity clinical areas to promote patient safety and enhance quality learning opportunities for students. During NUR 413 - Synthesis of Clinical Knowledge for Nursing Practice, each student is placed with a preceptor (1:1 ratio). Documentation available in the Virtual Resource Room. The criteria for the ratio of faculty to graduate student clinical supervision was derived from the NONPF NTF criteria and delineated in the CON's Workload policy for faculty DOE. Faculty workload is typically 1:6 ratio for a three- credit course with additional time given if more than six graduate students are assigned. Preceptors are based on a 1:1 ratio. Documentation available in the Virtual Resource Room. II-F. Preceptors (e.g., mentors, guides, coaches), if used by the program as an extension of faculty, are academically and experientially qualified for their role. This key element is not applicable to a degree or certificate program that does not use preceptors. Elaboration: The roles and performance expectations for preceptors with respect to teaching, supervision, and student evaluation are: clearly defined and communicated to preceptors; congruent with the mission, goals, and expected student outcomes; congruent with relevant professional nursing standards and guidelines; and reviewed periodically and revised as appropriate. Preceptors have the expertise to support student achievement of expected outcomes. The program ensures that preceptor performance meets expectations. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Students in the BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs all participate in clinical experiences with preceptors in practice settings. The goal of the CON is to provide clinical experiences that prepare the student for practice in a variet y of settings based on both the requirements of the program and student needs. The CON track coordinators facilitate this process, ensuring students are assigned knowledgeable and experienced clinicians as preceptors and that meet the criteria of the CON for precepting students. Once the faculty member identifies an agency and preceptor, they complete a Clinical Education Request Form which is submitted to the CON's practice & clinical engagement contract administrator. The contract administrator negotiates the specifics of the contractual agreement in collaboration with the UKHC legal department. This includes defining the goals and responsibilities of both the clinical site and the CON in addition to providing proof of licensure, malpractice, and HIPAA compliance. This agreement is in place prior to the student's experience. Databases of preceptors and clinical facilities are maintained electronically by the CON and the UK Legal Office and are updated every five years as needed. Documentation available in the Virtual Resource Room . BSN students are assigned to a preceptor during the Synthesis course. Students are placed wit h a preceptor at a 1:1 ratio. The Synthesis course was designed to provide opportunities to develop independence and competence in applying principles of care management and leadership to nursing practice in a variety of clinical settings. Synthesis students are paired with nurse preceptors for a 175-hour clinical practicum during the last semester of their senior year (KBN requires 120 hours). The students also devote 25 clinical hours developing a formal clinical reflection paper and presentation, which is a requirement of the University. CON clinical faculty oversee the student clinical experience and are responsible for evaluating student success. Nurse preceptors provide personal guidance and direct supervision as students deliver bedside clinical care or engage in public health nursing. Preceptors submit formal, written evaluation comments about student performance to clinical faculty at the mid-point and at the end of the rotation. Documentation available in the Virtual Resource Room. Clinical preceptors are oriented to their role by the clinical course coordinator. The Undergraduate preceptor handbook, available in the Virtual Resource Room , contains information regarding the role and responsibility of the student, preceptor and faculty and is reviewed with the preceptor prior to beginning the 30 semester. Faculty review preceptor and clinical site evaluations to determine if specific preceptor s and sites are conducive to the achievement of the student learning outcomes. If during the student's clinical rotation, they are not meeting the student learning outcomes and is related to either concerns with the preceptor or clinical site, the student clinical assignment is changed. Lastly, if issues with either the preceptor or clinical site cannot be resolved, they are not used in future semesters. Clinical assignments for the specialty courses of the DNP and Post-Graduate APRN Certificate options are also assigned at a 1:1 student to preceptor ratio, and on average a faculty to student ratio of 1:6. Preceptors are recruited by the track coordinators; sometimes the requests of individual students may be taken into consideration. The minimum educational requirements for preceptors are advanced practice preparation, experience in the specialty area in which the stu dent will practice (e.g., NP) verification of unencumbered and unrestricted licensure, and certification, if applicable. The minimum practice experience for preceptors is one - year practicing in their current role, but most of the advanced practice precept ors have been in practice for several years. Both students and faculty evaluate the preceptor and clinical site after each experience. Documents available in the Virtual Resource Room. Clinical preceptors are oriented to their role by the specialty track coordinators and faculty assigned for clinical supervision of students. They receive a Preceptor Handbook, available in the Virtual Resource Room, with details regarding their role, the student's role and faculty's role, and a signed form is returned indic ating their understanding. They are provided with a course syllabus and with ongoing opportunities for dialogue with course faculty via site visits. Ongoing evaluation by the faculty consists of phone or email contact with the preceptor in addition to week ly patient encounter logs, in Typhon, by each student during their clinical experience, which is reviewed by the faculty. The MSN students and those in the executive leadership in healthcare and clinical leadership in healthcare tracks of the DNP program work with a preceptor as approved by the student's advisor, who has expertise in the student's area of interest for their project. The preceptor may consult with the student throughout the program and may participate in the student's committee. It is preferred that preceptors are prepared at the doctoral level. The preceptors are oriented to their role by the track coordinator and faculty assigned for clinical supervision of students. They receive a Preceptor Handbook, available in the Virtual Resource Room, with details regarding their role, the student's role and faculty's role, and a signed form is returned indicating their understanding. They are provided with a course syllabus and with ongoing opportunities for dialogue with course faculty via site visits. Ongoing evaluation by the faculty consists of phone or email contact with the preceptor in addition to weekly logs, in Canvas®, by each student during their clinical experience, which is reviewed by the course faculty. II-G. The parent institution and program provide and support an environment that encourages faculty teaching, scholarship, service, and practice in keeping with the mission, goals, and expected faculty outcomes. Elaboration: Institutional support is available to promote faculty outcomes congruent with defined expectations of the faculty role (full- time, part -time, adjunct, tenured, non -tenured, or other) and in support of the mission, goals, and expected faculty outcomes. Faculty have opportunities for ongoing development in teaching. If scholarship is an expected faculty outcome, the institution provides resources to support faculty scholarship. If service is an expected faculty outcome, expected service is clearly defined and supported. If practice is an expected faculty outcome, opportunities are provided for faculty to maintain practice competence. Institutional support ensures that currency in clinical practice is maintained for faculty in roles that require it. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in co mpliance with this Key Element. The University supports and encourages faculty in the roles of teaching, scholarship, service, and practice. The University provides a wealth of opportunities for nursing faculty to engage in the multi- dimensional mission 31 of teaching, scholarship, service, and practice. While each of these types of activities is valued and encouraged, CON structures and processes allow for role assignments and progressions that accentuate individual strengths and interests. For example, the CON follows UK's five different types of faculty appointments: Regular Title Series - a traditional tenure- track with emphasis on re search and teaching; Clinical Title Series - non-tenure eligible with an emphasis on practice and teaching; Special Title Series - a tenure -track hybrid combination with the teaching, scholarship, service and practice expectations, as appropriate and individualized to the role; Research Title Series - non-tenure eligible with an emphasis on research; and Lecture Title Series - non-tenure eligible with an emphasis on t eaching. The DOE percentage is illustrated in Table IIG -1: Faculty Distribution of Effort by Title Series . Additionally, the CON engages several experts from nursing and other health -related disciplines as part-time, adjunct, and voluntary faculty members. Table IIG -1 Faculty Distribution of Effort by Title Series Teaching Research/ Scholarship Practice Service Regular Title 5-10% Teaching Support Faculty members have opportunities for ongoing development in teaching and pedagogy, research and scholarship, specialty practice, and service. Newly hired faculty members are paired with a senior faculty mentor to assist them with tasks such as syllabus preparation, content development, and classroom management. For example, new faculty in the undergraduate program, in conjunction with the program Associate Dean, develop a comprehensive educational and mentoring plan to support them in their new role. This is a requirement of the Kentucky Board of Nursing and exemplars can be found in the Virtual Resource Room . New faculty in the graduate programs attend a CON orientation, develop an informal plan for success and are paired with a mentor to support them in their new role. Documentation available in the Virtual Resource Room . In both programs, initially faculty mentors work closely with their mentees to assist them in acclimating to the teaching role. The Center for the Enhancement of Learning and Teaching (CELT) also offers ongoing faculty development opportunities. This department employs several instructional designers and experts in web- based delivery and technological modalities to support teaching. The mission of the CELT is to promote and support excellence in teaching and learning at UK by working collaboratively with all instructors to create engaging, innovative, and inclusive learning environments in which diverse students can excel. The Faculty Media Depot offers ongoing faculty support with the creation and conversion of audio and video materials to transition to online and alternative formats for course delivery. The services are offered primarily by appointment either in person or virtually. In addition, they have audio and video recording studios that faculty can utilize to develop professional presentations. The services are offered primarily by appointment either in person or virtually. The CON supports faculty to attend conferences at local, regional, national, and international venues through travel funds. In addition, the funds can also be used for nursing faculty to attend and present at regional, national, and international conferences. Research and Scholarship Support Ranked #14 among colleges of nursing among public universities for NIH research funding, the CON and UK offer extensive support services to assist faculty with their research and scholarship endeavors. New Regular Title Series faculty have 10- to 12-month appointments and are given 50% release time and start-up funding (e.g., $25,000 - $50,000/year x 3 years) to develop their programs of research. The Associate Dean for Research meets individually with new tenure -track faculty to develop a detailed plan for their research or scholarship trajectory and provides mentorship and individual consultations over time. The CON commits to a Distribution of Effort (DOE) /protected time for scholarship/research for n ewly-hired, Regular Title Series tenure- track faculty for a range of 30% to 55% with the expectation of funding support within three years of appointment. 32 The CON Office for Nursing Research employs two statisticians, an expert in survey development and administration, and two grants managers who provide research support to faculty members. Faculty also have access to the services of an editor and a health librarian to support their research. This office also manages the indirect funds the College receives from extramural grants. The CON houses several research groups, including the Bridging Research Efforts and A dvocacy Toward Health Environments (BREATHE) Team, the Research and Interventions for C ardiovascular Health (RICH) H eart Research Team, the P erinatal Research and Wellness Center, the Behavior Health and W ellness Environments for L iving and L earning (BH WELL) Team and the Community Health Advocacy i Nterventions Generating Equity (CHANGE) Team, which offer junior faculty the opportunity to engage with large interprofessional research teams and senior researchers. These teams have also provided small scale seed grants to support faculty research. Additionally, UK provides a variety of small scale start up grants which have helpe d to support several of our nurse investigators. Support for Practice and Service In the CON, faculty practice is one of the most prominent means of community engagement. Faculty practice serves as a basis for scholarship, and provides opportunities to maintain clinical competence and credentials, supervise and mentor students in practi ce settings, and demonstrate innovative practice models. During the past year, 20 nursing faculty members have participated in practice activities. As discussed earlier, the Phyllis D. Corbitt Center had been closed for two years due to her retirement when the CON reopened the facility. The Center serves as a practice site for several faculty members as well as a clinical site for FNP students. The Faculty Practice Council continues to foster communication among faculty practitioners, administrators, and community partners. Participants benefit from the opportunity to share information related to the College Practice Plan, as well as new developments in the work of individual faculty practitioners, and changes in advanced practice nursing across the local region and the nation. A current project of this council is to review survey results related to the landscape for faculty practice (trends and benchmark s) and make recommendations for Faculty Bylaws changes to ensure relevance of the council's purpose and core function. The CON consistently works closely with UKHC to strengthen integration of academic nursing operations. The Dean's revised organizational leadership structure assures alignment for nursing leaders to actively engage in joint strategic planning and operational management for education, practice and research. These relationships help facilitate opportunities for shared resources and practice contracts. The shared faculty positions, post -BSN Nurse Residency Program, and the annual Nursing Research Papers Day are some of the most prominent examples of these collaborative partnerships. CON faculty are also encouraged and supported to engage in a wide range of other service and engagement activities. Service time is incorporated into all faculty workload plans. All faculty members are encouraged to serve on at least two committees, including committees within the CON and those representing the larger University. Nursing faculty are active participants in UK governance, participating on the Faculty Senate, the Hea lth Care Colleges Advisory Council, the Institutional Review Boards, CIHERP, and many others. Several of the CON faculty hold leadership positions on health -related committees, boards, or offices external to the CON. When faculty are involved in key leade rship positions at the state, national, and international levels, additional workload release/distribution of effort (DOE) adjustments and financial support for participation are provided. The University and the CON have also encouraged and supported faculty to develop and expand international collaborative partnerships. For example, the University has a long -standing partnership with a community and clinic in Ecuador, referred to as Shoulder -to-Shoulder Global. Over the past five years, 20 CON students and faculty have travelled to Ecuador annually with interprofessional teams for short -term visits to provide primary care, promote public health, participate in and initiate research, and prov ide health education and health promotion to this Ecuadorian community. From 2017- 2020, active international partnerships and scholarship involving CON faculty have increased, including new activities in Ecuador, Ghana, Sweden, Peru, China, and Korea. Our global learning and engagement extended to Education Abroad programs in Costa Rica, Sweden, and the Netherlands, where 12 CON students were engaged with learning about longevity, health systems and sexual health. When the students returned from these experiences, they provided forums to educate and enrich the local population to improve health in central Kentucky. 33 In terms of cross -cultural community engagement experiences in Appalachia, the CON has continued to expand opportunities for students in eastern Kentucky. We have maintained our partnership with the College of Dentistry and the UK Center for Interprofessional Health Education to promote oral health and wellness through a program known as hCATS (health colleges advancing team skills) to Appalachia. This engagement included over 60 nursing students in 2018 and 2019, who worked with dental and other health professional students, in five elementary schools to deliver oral health care, health screening and wellness education. Since 2018, a HRSA - funded program has supported 10 CON undergraduate and graduate students to provide primary care services for Appalachians. Twenty undergraduate and graduate students and faculty participate in the Remote Area Medical (RAM) U.S.A. program providing primary care services, health screenings and wellness programs in Hazard, Kentucky. In addition to providing support and resources for teaching, research, practice and service, the CON and UK provide several awards each year to recognize exemplary performance in each of these categories. The CON hosts a year -end celebration each May where those faculty and staff members who demonstrated ex emplary accomplishments in teaching, scholarship and practice are recognized. CON award recipients are annually updated and displayed in the 3rd floor corridor "hall of recognition." 34 STANDARD II Summary: Institutional Commitment and Resources Levels of Strength of Quality Strong Strength of Quality The University of Kentucky and UK Healthcare have supported the College of Nursing's mission to advance excellence with academic programming, research, clinical practice, and service through fiscal and physical resources. The College of Nursing has an impr essive research portfolio with extramural awards to help augment/support recruitment and retention of faculty researchers, pilot funding for faculty, access to research team/facilities and scholarly activities for students. The College of Nursing has innovative faculty practice initiatives and professional development initiatives to help augment/support fiscal resources. The College of Nursing has an exceptional faculty base of nationally recognized academic leaders, educators, practitioners, and researchers. The College of Nursing has a strong commitment to advance simulated learning resources and promote student mental health and wellness. Moderate to High Strength of Quality The College of Nursing has national rankings/recognition for academic clinical partnerships (NLN Center for Nursing Education Excellence). The College of Nursing is highly integrated with UK HealthCare, a Magnet designated academic health center - UK HealthCare. The College of Nursing is highly integrated with one of the fir st CCNE accredited Nurse Residency programs in the country - UK HealthCare. The College of Nursing has adequate physical resources and clinical sites to fulfill the mission, goals, and expected outcomes. The College of Nursing has well established communi ty of supporters and donors to help advance philanthropy goals. The College of Nursing has a strong commitment for faculty advancement and competitive salaries for recruitment and retention.
