The College of Nursing recognizes the highly valued academic -clinical partnership with UK HealthCare requires on -going efforts t o sustain and/or advance fiscal agreements with clinical faculty hires and performance goals support. The College of Nursing recognizes the challenge of rebuilding program growth by expanding academic clinical partnerships beyond UK HealthCare and Select M edical to advance nursing education. The College of Nursing recognizes the challenges of meeting and/or exceeding the UK Capital Campaign goals during a pandemic. The College of Nursing recognizes the challenges of state- budget constraints salary advances, new hires, facility upgrades and/or new building projects. The College of Nursing recognizes the challenges to rebuild faculty workforce will require intentional efforts to fill the teaching/mentoring gaps. 35 Standard III Program Quality: Curriculum and Teaching- Learning Practices The curriculum is developed in accordance with the program's mission, goals, and expected student outcomes. The curriculum reflects professional nursing standards and guidelines and the needs and expectations of t he community of interest. Teaching -learning practices are congruent with expected student outcomes. The environment for teaching -learning fosters achievement of expected student outcomes. III-A. The curriculum is developed, implemented, and revised to ref lect clear statements of expected student outcomes that: are congruent with the program's mission and goals; are congruent with the roles for which the program is preparing its graduates; and consider the needs of the program -identified community of intere st. Elaboration: Curricular objectives (e.g., course, unit, and/or level objectives or competencies as identified by the program) provide clear statements of expected learning that relate to student outcomes. Expected outcomes relate to the roles for whic h students are being prepared. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The BSN, MSN, DNP Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs' curricula are based on and are congruent with the mission and goals of the CON. All programs undergo formative and summative evaluations each semester and no less than every three years as outlined in the CON Systematic Process of Program Evaluation (CON SPPE) . The course syllabi for the BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs include clear, expected student learning outcomes (SLOs) as well as student activities to assure the course SLOs are met. The faculty developed a curriculum crosswalk for each track of the respective programs. The respective program committees evaluate all courses using a designated format and timeline and outcomes are reviewed with the course faculty. Curricula are revised based on the course review, student evaluations, faculty expertise, information from employers and the nursing standards to assure success in the program and beyond. The BSN program has undergone significant curricular revisions, specifically transitioning the second - degree track to an Accelerated BSN (ABSN) track which will include Med- Vet, second degree and Licensed Practical Nurse to Bachelor of Science in Nursing (LPN -to-BSN) students. In addition, the undergraduate faculty have made curricular revisions to the traditional and RN -BSN tr acks to improve overall efficiencies and effectiveness of teaching as well as improve retention and time to degree rates. The Program SLOs for the BSN program apply to all baccalaureate nursing students. Crosswalks have been developed for each track in the BSN program. (Appendix IIIA-1) The expected outcomes at the completion of the program are that the graduate will: Integrate knowledge, skills, and values from the arts and sciences to provide humanistic, safe, quality care (AACN Essential I: Liberal Education for Baccalaureate Generalist Nursing Practice). Demonstrate clinical reasoning in making independent and collaborative decisions in a complex health care system (AACN Essential II: Basic Organizational and Systems Leadership for Quality Care and Patient Safety) Apply a systematic process consistent with professional standards and evidence- based practice to prevent illness and injury; promote, maintain, and restore client health; or support clients toward a peaceful death (AACN Essential I II: Scholarship for Evidence- Based Practice). Demonstrate skills in using patient care technologies, information systems, and communication devices that support safe and effective care (AACN Essential IV: Information Management and Application of Patient Care Technology). Demonstrate leadership, responsibility, and accountability in addressing health care issues (AACN Essential V: Healthcare Policy, Finance, and Regulatory Environments). Employ oral and written communication and inter -professional collaboration in providing safe, high quality care to improve client health outcomes (AACN Essential VI: Interprofessional Communication and Collaboration for Improving Patient Health Outcomes). 36 Demonstrate caring, professionalism, and respect in providing nursing care to diverse populations in a variety of settings (AACN Essential VII: Clinical Prevention and Population Health). Demonstrate the professional standards of moral, ethical, and legal conduct (Essential VIII: Professionalism and Profess ional Values). Understand the scope of generalist nursing practice and apply its principles in clinical practice (Essential IX: Baccalaureate Generalist Nursing Practice). The MSN curriculum, focusing on Healthcare Systems Leadership, was developed in 201 8 and implemented in 2019. The MSN/DNP program committee reviews the curriculum to assure compliance with professional standards. The course syllabi include clear, expected SLOs as well as student activities to assure the course SLOs are met. Faculty reviewed the curriculum and developed a crosswalk for the MSN Program. (Appendix IIIA-2) The Program Student Learning Outcomes are based on the Essentials of Master's Education in Nursing for the MSN Program and are applicable to all MSN students. The expected outcomes at the completion of the program are that the graduate will: Lead change to improve quality outcomes. Advance a culture of excellence through lifelong learning. Build and lead collaborative inter- professional care teams. Navigate and integrate care services across the healthcare system. Design innovative nursing practices. Translate evidence into practice. The DNP curriculum was revised in 2015 to assure better alignment with the DNP Essentials with the SLOs in preparation for the implementation of the DNP Portfolio. The MSN/DNP program committee reviews the curriculum to assure compliance with professional nursing standards. The faculty reviewed the curriculum and developed a crosswalk for each track in the DNP program. (Appendix IIIA -3) The Program Student Learning Outcomes for the DNP Program apply to all DNP students. The expected outcomes at the completion of the program are that the graduate will: Integrate nursing science and theory with knowledge from ethics, the biophysical, psychosocial, analytical, and organizational sciences as the basis for nursing practice (AACN Essential I: Scientific Underpinnings for Practice). Demonstrate advanced organi zational and systems leadership that emphasizes practice and the ongoing improvement of health outcomes (AACN Essential II: Organizational and Systems Leadership for Quality Improvement and Systems Thinking). Generate, translates, applies, and evaluates new science/evidence to guide improvements in practice and outcomes of care (AACN Essential III: Clinical Scholarship and Analytical Methods for Evidence Based Practice). Demonstrate proficient use of information systems/ technology resources to implement quality improvement initiatives and support practice and administrative decision -making (AACN Essential IV: Information Systems/Technology and Patient Care Technology for the Improvement and Transformation of Health Care). Engage proactively in the analysis, development, and implementation of health policy at the institutional, local, state, regional, federal, or international level (AACN Essential V: Health Care Policy for Advocacy in Health Care). Employ consultative and l eadership skills with intra - and inter- professional teams to create change in health care and complex healthcare delivery systems (AACN Essential VI: Inter- professional Collaboration for Improving Patient and Population Health Outcomes). Analyze, synthesiz es, and evaluates scientific data and concepts related to clinical prevention and population health, and gaps in care of individuals, aggregates, or populations (AACN Essential VII: Clinical Prevention and Population Health for Improving the Nation's Health). Demonstrate foundational practice competencies that cut across specialties (AACN Essential VIII: Advanced Nursing Practice specialties). The MSN/DNP program committee reviews curriculum of the program to assure compliance with professional standards. The Post-Graduate APRN Certificate program curriculum is identical to the specialty core 37 of the respective tracks in the DNP program. The purpose of the Post-Graduate APRN Certificate program is intended for nurses who currently have an advanced practice graduate degree in nursing (MSN, DNP, PhD) who wish to specialize in a different population foci other than that obtained/certified in the degree program. The program is designed to broaden the cl inical knowledge in the new role change. The program student learning outcomes for the Post -Graduate APRN Certificate program apply to all APRN students and Executive Leadership students. The expected outcomes at the completion of the program are that the graduate will: Integrate nursing science and theory with knowledge from ethics, the biophysical, psychosocial, analytical, and organizational sciences as the basis for nursing practice. Translate, apply, and evaluate new science/evidence to guide improvements in practice and outcomes of care. Employ consultative and leadership skills with intra - and inter -professional teams to create change in health care and complex healthcare delivery systems. III-B. Baccalaureate curricula are developed, implemented, and revised to reflect relevant professional nursing standards and guidelines, which are clearly evident within the curriculum and within the expected student outcomes (individual and aggregate). Baccalau reate program curricula incorporate The Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice (AACN, 2008). This key element is not applicable if the baccalaureate degree program is not under review for accreditation. Elaboration: The b accalaureate degree program incorporates professional nursing standards and guidelines relevant to that program and each track offered. The program clearly demonstrates where and how content, knowledge, and skills required by identified sets of standards are incorporated into the curriculum. Program Response: The BSN Program is in compliance with this Key Element. The BSN degree program is based on The Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice (BSN Essentials) (AACN 2008) and the six core Quality & Safety Education for Nurses (QSEN) Competencies. The BSN Essentials and QSEN Competencies (AACN, 2008) form the foundation f or the undergraduate curriculum in the CON. The core concepts of the nursing program curriculum are: Patient - Centered Care; Communication and Interprofessional Collaboration; Clinical Reasoning; Professionalism; ems and Policy; Evidence- Based Practice; Quality Improvement and Patient Safety; Information Management/Informatics; and Health Promotion and Disease and Injury Prevention. The expected student learning outcomes are consistent with the roles for which the program is preparing its graduates. The BSN Program has three entry points: Traditional BSN, ABSN (second degree, Med Vet BSN, and LPN-BSN) and RN-BSN. The curricula consist of a series of didactic courses and clinical experiences that facilitate the achievement of the program SLOs through the course content as reflected in the crosswalk documents for each track. (Appendix IIIA-1) The courses and content progress from the simple to complex as the students advance in the curriculum. In the freshman year, students complete pre- nursing requirements which provide core knowledge that prepares them for learning nursing concepts. In the sophomore year, students learn and practice fundamental nursing knowledge and skills that will be used throug hout the curriculum, with the major emphasis on health promotion and health maintenance. During this year, students spend much of their clinical time in community and skills laboratory settings. In the junior year, the focus shifts to care of the patient a nd family in several health care settings (medical -surgical, obstetrics and pediatrics), with a focus on care of patients with predictable outcomes. In the first semester of the senior year, students must bring their previous learning forward to work in the areas of psychiatric/mental health and public health. In the second semester, the curriculum begins with the care of patients with complex, unpredictable outcomes (critical care), and ends with a synthesis immersion clinical experience that facilitates students' ability to apply what they have learned while working one- to-one with a nurse preceptor. 38 These teaching learning practices facilitate the achievement of the program SLOs and the BSN Essentials (AACN, 2008). For example, a focus on critical thinking, clinical reasoning and clinical judgement can be found in all courses within the curricula. All examinations and clinical experiences require students to apply knowledge gained to enhance their ability to make sound clinical decisions. The curricular plans for each track listed below can be found on the UK CON website. Traditional BSN RN-BSN Accelerated BSN Second Degree BSN MedVet -BSN LPN-BSN Changes to the respective curriculum plans can be found in the virtual resource room. III-C. All master's degree programs that prepare nurse practitioners incorporate Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs (NTF, 2016). Graduate -entry master's program curricula incorporate T he Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice (AACN, 2008) and appropriate graduate program standards and guidelines. This key element is not applicable if the master's degree program is not under review for accreditation. Elaboration: The master's degree program incorporates professional nursing standards and guidelines relevant to that program and each track offered. The program clearly demonstrates where and how content, knowledge, and skills required by i dentified sets of standards are incorporated into the curricula. Master's degree APRN education programs (i.e., clinical nurse specialist, nurse anesthesia, nurse midwife, and nurse practitioner) incorporate separate comprehensive graduate- level courses t o address the APRN core, defined as follows: Advanced physiology/pathophysiology, including general principles that apply across the lifespan; Advanced health assessment, which includes assessment of all human systems, advanced assessment techniques, concepts, and approaches; and Advanced pharmacology, which includes pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapeutics of all broad categories of agents. Additional APRN core content specific to the role and population is integrated throughout the other role and population -focused didactic and clinical courses. Master's degree programs that have a direct care focus but are not APRN education programs (e.g., nurse educator and clinical nurse leader) incorporate graduate- level content addressing the APRN core. These programs are not required to offer this content as three separate courses. Program Response: The MSN Program is in compliance with this Key Element. The MSN program is based on The Essentials of Master's Education in Nursing ( MSN Essentials) (AACN , 2011). The MSN program builds on the student's undergraduate degree, and current knowledge and expertise. 39 Graduates that complete this program will have a fuller understanding of the discipline of nursing in order to engage in higher- level practice and leadership in a variety of settings and to commit to lifelong learning. The curriculum consists of a series of didactic courses and clinical experiences that facilitate the achievement of the program SLOs through the course content as reflected in the crosswalk document for the MSN program. (Appendix IIIA-2). The program prepares students to function as change agents in multi -dimensional roles in the organization and community. Research utilization, evidence- based practice, and leadership are emphasized throughout the program. The program is delivered in an online format using Zoom and the learning management system Canvas®. Teaching -learning practices are incorporated throughout the program to facilitate the achievement of the MSN Essentials (AACN, 2011) and the program SLOs for example leadership theory and its application is threaded through the didactic courses and clinical experiences which culminates in the MSN capstone practicum. The full-time and part-time curricular plans for the MSN program can be found on CON website. III-D. DNP curr icula are developed, implemented, and revised to reflect relevant professional nursing standards and guidelines, which are clearly evident within the curriculum and within the expected student outcomes (individual and aggregate). DNP program curricula incorporate professional standards and guidelines as appropriate. a. All DNP programs incorporate The Essentials of Doctoral Education for Advanced Nursing Practice (AACN, 2006) and additional relevant professional standards and guidelines if identified by the program . b. All DNP programs that prepare nurse practitioners incorporate Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs (NTF, 2016). Graduate -entry DNP program curricula incorporate The Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice (AACN, 2008) and appropriate graduate program standards and guidelines. This key element is not applicable if the DNP program is not under review for accreditation. Elaboration: The DNP program incorporates professional nursing standards and guidelines relevant to that program and each track offered. The program clearly demonstrates where and how content, knowledge, and skills required by identified sets of standards are incorporated into the curricula. DNP APRN education programs (i.e., clinical nurse specialist, nurse anesthesia, nurse midwife, and nurse practitioner) incorporate separate comprehensive graduate- level c ourses to address the APRN core, defined as follows: Advanced physiology/pathophysiology, including general principles that apply across the lifespan; Advanced health assessment, which includes assessment of all human systems, advanced assessment techniques, concepts, and approaches; and Advanced pharmacology, which includes pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapeutics of all broad categories of agents. Additional APRN core content specific to the role and population is integrated throughou t the other role and population -focused didactic and clinical courses. Separate courses in advanced physiology/pathophysiology, advanced health assessment, and advanced pharmacology are not required for students enrolled in post -master's DNP programs who hold current national certification as advanced practice nurses, unless the program deems this necessary. Program Response: The DNP Program is in compliance with this Key Element. The DNP Program is based on: The Essentials of Doctoral Education for Advanced Nursing Practice (DNP Essentials (AACN,2006); Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs (NONPF, 2016); Nurse Practitioner Core Competencies (NONPF, 2017); Population Focused NP Competencies (NONPF, 2013); Nurse Executive Comp etencies (AONE, 2015), and Core Practice Doctorate Clinical Nurse Specialist Competencies (NACNS, 2009) 40 for the respective foci. The DNP Program offers two entry points, BSN -DNP and MSN- DNP. The BSN -DNP entry is comprised of two advanced practice registered nurse (APRN) roles, Nurse Practitioner and Clinical Nurse Specialist, which was closed to admissions in 2019 and the two remaining students are on track to graduate in 2021. Teach out plans available in the Virtual Resource Room . The decision to close th e track was based on declining enrollment concerns and COI feedback. The six population foci areas available include: Adult - Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner (AGACNP) ; Pediatric Acute Care Nurse Practitioner (PACNP) ; Pediatric Primary Care Nurse Practitioner (PPCNP) ; Family Nurse Practitioner (FNP) ; Psychiatric -Mental Health Nurse Practitioner (PMHNP) ; and Executive Leadership in Health Care. The MSN -DNP entry is comprised of the Clinical Leadership in Health Care in addition to the six popu lation foci previously listed. Separate courses in advanced health assessment, pathophysiology, and advanced pharmacology for advanced practice nurses are included for the APRN Roles. Based on feedback from our COI, the program transitioned from a traditio nal face -to-face delivery model to an online delivery model with an immersion component. The students attend on -campus classes twice during the semester for immersion sessions to accommodate for the components of the program which are difficult to achieve in an online environment. For example, during the first immersion, NP students enrolled in their first clinical course except for PMHNP are taught skills/techniques in suturing, ultrasound, punch biopsy, incision and draining of wounds and debridement of w ounds. The track coordinators work collaboratively to teach the skills as well as offer the opportunity for the students to experience their first collaboration with other NPs. All students in the DNP program have content related to nursing leadership, and during each immersion all DNP students are required to attend the Nursing Leadership Lecture Series, which is co-sponsored by the UK CON and UK Healthcare. Students can hear from nationally and internationally recognized nurse leaders, of which the vast majority are alumni (See Appendix IIID-1). In 2014 the University of Kentucky College of Nursing established a new off -campus instructional site, the University of Kentucky College of Nursing - Norton Healthcare Partnership (UKCON -NHC), located at 9500 Ormsby Station Road, Louisville, Kentucky 40223, and began enrolling students into the three -year, full -time DNP program. The UKCON -NHC Partnership, which ceased admissions in 2018, was not independent; it provided the same SLOs, curricular content and experiences, and assessments as the UK CON Lexington campus, and was under the authority of UK CON. The students in the partnership were enrolled in the same courses as the non - partnership students. The partnership students attended classes at the Norton Hea lth Care site while the others attend on the UK campus. The tracks offered in the DNP program at the CON-NHC site included Adult Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner, Primary Care Nurse Practitioner (Adult -Gerontology and Family), Executive Nurse Leadership, Population and Organizational Systems Leadership, and Psychiatric Mental -Health Nurse Practitioner. The didactic portion of the curriculum was delivered through a variety of hybrid modalities including face- to- face and online classes. At both sites (Lexington and Louisville), the courses met 4 -5 times per semester face- to-face, with the r emaining content accessed online through Canvas®, the University of Kentucky's learning management system. The last of the partnership students graduated in May 2020. The curricular plans are available in the Virtual Resource Room. The curricular plans fo r each track in the BSN -DNP entry and MSN -DNP entry listed below can be found on the UK CON website. Post-graduate APRN certificate program curricula are developed, implemented, and revised to reflect relevant professional nursing standards and guidelines, which are clearly evident within the curriculum and within the expected student outcomes (individual and aggregate). Post -graduate 41 APRN certificate programs that prepare nurse practitioners incorporate Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs (NTF, 2016). This key element is not applicable if the post -graduate APRN certificate program is not under review for accreditation. Elaboration: The post -graduate APRN certificate program incorporates professional nursing standards and guidelines relevant to that program and each track offered. The program clearly demonstrates where and how content, k nowledge, and skills required by identified sets of standards are incorporated into the curricula. APRN education programs (i.e., clinical nurse specialist, nurse anesthesia, nurse midwife, and nurse practitioner) incorporate separate comprehensive graduate -level courses to address the APRN core, defined as follows: Advanced physiology/pathophysiology, including general principles that apply across the lifespan; Advanced health assessment, which includes assessment of all human systems, advanced assessment techniques, concepts, and approaches; and Advanced pharmacology, which includes pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapeutics of all broad categories of agents. Additional APRN core content specific to the role and population is integrated throughout the other role- and population -focused didactic and clinical courses. Program Response: The Post -Graduate Certificate Program is in compliance with this Key Element. The Post-Graduate APRN Certificate program is based on components of the MSN Essentials (AACN, 2011); DNP Essentials (AACN, 2006); Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs (NONPF, 2016); and Nurse Practitioner Core Competencies (NONPF, 2017) for the respective population foci. A Gap Analysis is completed on the student transcripts to determine which courses can be transferred in and those that will need to be taken as part of the Post-Graduate APRN Certificate program. Examples available in the Virtual Resource Room . If the student has not completed advanced health assessment, advance d pharmacology, and advanced pathophysiology as three separate courses they will complete those as a component of the program. The curriculum for the Post- Graduate APRN Certificate Program consists of the specialty courses in the DNP program. The students are integrated with the DNP students to attend on -campus classes twice during the semester for immersion sessions to accommodate for the components of the program that are difficult to achieve in an online environment. During immersion, the Post -Graduate APRN Certificate students participate in the same planned activities as the DNP students in the respective population foci. For example, during immersion II, students in the PMHNP track conduct a simulated diagnostic interview to develop a treatment plan. Graduates of the Post -Graduate APRN Certificate program (Adult Gerontology Acute Care NP, Family NP, Psychiatric Mental Health NP, Pediatric Acu te Care NP, and Pediatric Primary Care NP) are educated to make application to take the national certification examination in the selected population foci. The curricular plans for each track in the Post-Graduate APRN Certificate program can be found in the Virtual Resource Room and are posted on the following UK CON website . III-F. The curriculum is logically structured to achieve expected student outcomes. Baccalaureate curricula build on a foundation of the arts, sciences, and humanities. Master's curricula build on a foundation comparable to baccalaureate -level nursing knowledge. DNP curricula build on a baccalaureate and/or master's foundation, depending on the level of entry of the student. Post-graduate APRN certificate programs build on graduate -level nursing competencies and knowledge base. 42 Elaboration: Baccalaureate degree programs demonstrate that knowledge from courses in the arts, sciences, and humanities is incorporated into nursing practice. Graduate- entry programs in nursing incorporate the generalist knowledge common to baccalaureate nursing education as delineated in The Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice (AACN, 2008) as well as advanced nursing knowledge. Graduate programs are clearly based on a foundation comparable to a baccalaureate degree in nursing. Graduate programs delineate how students who do not have a baccalaureate degree in nursing acquire the knowledge and competencies comparable to baccalaureate education in nursing as a foundation for advanced nursing education. Programs that move students from basic nursing preparation (e.g., associate degree or diploma education) to a graduate degree demonstrate how these students acquire the baccalaureate- level knowledge and competencies delineated in The Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice (AACN, 2008), even if they do not award a baccalaureate degree in nursing in addition to the graduate degree. DNP programs, whether post -baccalaureate or post -master's, demonstrate how students acquire the doctoral- level know ledge and competencies delineated in The Essentials of Doctoral Education for Advanced Nursing Practice (AACN, 2006). If the program awards the master's degree as part of the DNP program, the program demonstrates how students acquire the master's- level knowledge and competencies delineated in The Essentials of Master's Education in Nursing (AACN, 2011) and, if applicable, Criteria for Evaluation of Nurse Practitioner Programs (NTF, 2016) . The program provides a rationale for the sequence of the curriculum for each program. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Baccalaureate Program The BSN Program is built upon a foundation of arts, sciences, and humanities through the required UK Core curriculum plan and support coursework. The 30 -credit hour UK Core curriculum is based on a set of SLOs that all students are expected to be able to demonstrate upon completion of a baccalaureate degree. The UK Core SLOs with the course areas are reflected in Table IIIF -1: UK Core Student Learning Outcome by Course Area. Nursing students are required to fulfill 10 credit hours of UK Core that support th eir educational foundations including psychology, biology, and statistics. In addition, they take Anatomy and Physiology I & II, Chemistry for Health Professionals, Microbiology, and Introductory Nutrition. Learning is viewed as being cumulative, with each level in the curriculum building on the previous levels. The foundation is laid in the UK Core courses and is critical to the development of the professional nurse and aligns with the UK CON Mission, Vision and Values statement . The UK College of Nursing provides three entry options for students to attain a Baccalaure ate of Science in Nursing: Traditional BSN, ABSN, and RN-BSN. The curriculum for each track has been revised and is delivered in a block format as reflected in the descriptions for each track. The curriculum for each track contains both didactic and clinical courses to assist students in the achievement of the BSN Essentials and the BSN program outcomes. Through these courses, students gain the needed knowledge and skills to provide direct and indirect care using the nursing process, integrating evidence -based practice, clinical judgement, and quality improvement activities. Table IIIF -1: UK Core Student Learning Outcome by Course Area UK Core SLO Course Area Credit Hour I. Students will demonstrate an understanding of 1. The Nature of Inquiry in Arts and Creativity 2. The Nature of Inquiry in the Humanities 3. The Nature of Inquiry in the Social Services 4. The Nature of Inquiry in the Natural, Physical and Mathematical Sciences 3 and ability to employ the processes of 3 intellectual inquiry. 3 3 II. Students will demonstrate competent written, 1. Composition and Communication I 3 oral, and visual communication skills both as 2. Composition and Communication II 3 producers and consumers of information. 43 III. Students will demonstrate an understanding of 1. Quantitative Foundations 3 and ability to employ methods of quantitative reasoning. 2. Statistical inferential Reasoning 3 IV. Students will demonstrate and understanding of the complexities of citizenship and the process for making informed choices as engaged citizens in a diverse, multilingual world. 1. Community, Cultural and Citizenship in the USA 2. Global Dynamics 3 3 The traditional BSN curriculum is a full -time, four -year degree comprised of 120 credit hours, which includes the 30 -credit hour UK Core as reflected on the UK Registrar's websit e. During their first year, students complete most of the UK Core requirements and the pre-major courses. Students complete the pre-major courses (25 credits) with a minimum of a C grade and include: ANA 109 Anatomy and Physiology for Nursing I and ANA 110 Anatomy and Physiology for Nursing II (8 credits); BIO 103 Basic Ideas of Biology (3 credits); CHE 103 Chemistry for Health Professionals (4 credits); CIS/WRD I Composition and Communication I and CIS/WRD II Composition and Communication II (6 credits); and PSY 100 Introduction to Psychology (4 credits). Students also complete the UK required Graduation Composition and Communication Requirement (11 credits). This requirement is embedded in NUR 200 Foundations for Professional Nursing (2 credits) ; NUR 310 Research for Evidence- Based Nursing Practice (3 credits); and NUR 413 Synthesis of Clinical Knowledge for Nursing Practice (6 credits). Beginning in their second year students complete additional courses in BIO 208 Principles of Microbiology (3 credits); DHN 212 Introduction to Nutrition (3 credits); and STA 210 Introduction to Statistical Reasoning or BST 230 Statistical Thinking in Public Health (3 credits). These courses provide the foundational knowledge of the arts, sciences, and humanities on which the program is built. The nursing courses comprise 68 credit hours (57%) of the total credits required for graduation and 47 credit hours (69%) are upper -division level. UK Core requirements account for 30 credit hours (26%) of the total credit hours. A sample plan of study of the nursing courses can be found on the UK CON website and course syllabi are available in the Virtual Resource Room . The ABSN track curriculum is a full -time, consecutive 24 -month curriculum comprised of 66 credit hours in nursing for a total of 120 credit hours, which includes meeting the 30- credit hour UK Core requirements. All applicants who have completed a bachelor's degree in another field meet the requirement by virtue of their first degree as reflected on the UK Registrar's website . As a component of the admission requirements, students must meet the UK Core and pre-major requirements. The pre-major courses include: ANA 109 Anatomy and Physiology for Nursing I and ANA 110 Anatomy and Physiology for Nursing II (8 credits); or ANA 209 Principles of Human Anatomy (3 credits); BIO 103 Basic Ideas of Biology (3 credits); or BIO 148 Introductory Biology I (3 credits); CHE 103 Chemistry for Hea lth Professionals (4 credits); or CHE 104 Introductory General Chemistry (3 credits) and CHE 108 Introduction to Inorganic, Organic and Biochemistry without laboratory (3 credits); or CHE 105 General College Chemistry I (4 credits) and Che 107 General College Chemistry II (3 credits); and PSY 100 Introduction to Psychology (4 credits). Students also complete the UK -required Graduation Composition and Communication Requirement (8-10 credits). This requirement is embedded in NUR 321 Introduction to Health Promotion for ABSN Students (2 credits); NUR 328 Research for Evidence Based Nursing Practice for the ABSN (3 credits); and NUR 426 Synthesis of Clinical Nursing Knowledge for the ABSN Track (3- 5 credits). Students complete additional courses in BIO 208 Principles of Microbiology (3 credits); DHN 212 Introduction to Nutrition (3 credits); and STA 210 An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning or BST 230 Statistical Thinking in Public Health or STA 296 Statistical Methods and Motivations (3 credits). Th e curriculum culminates in NUR 426 - Synthesis of Clinical Nursing Knowledge for the ABSN Track where students integrate knowledge from previous courses to develop independence and competence in applying principles of care management and leadership to nurs ing practice in a variety of settings. The course syllabi are available in the Virtual Resource Room and a sample plan of study of the nursing courses can be found on the UK CON website . The RN -BSN track may be completed in either a two -year, consecutive part -time option or a one -year, consecutive full -time option. The tr ack is comprised of 30 -33 credits hours in nursing, for a total of 120 credits which includes meeting the 30 -hour UK Core requirements. The UK Core curriculum requirement for RN -BSN students is as follows: Per the General Education Transfer Agreement (GETA ), students who earn an Associate of Arts or an Associate of Science degree are considered to have met the general education requirements of the UK 44 CORE. Students who earn an Associate of Applied Science (which includes most students from Kentucky Community and Technical College System [KCTCS] schools) must complete general education requirements of the UK Core. If they have not met the UK Core with their previous degree, then they will complete those courses in addition to the nursing courses as reflected on the UK Registrar's website . Students also complete the UK -required Graduation Composition and Communication Requirement (8 credits). This requirement is embedded in NUR 350 Concepts in Professional Nursing (5 credits) and NUR 453 Nursing Practice Capstone for Registered Nurses for the RN -BSN Track (3 credits). The curriculum culminates in NUR 453 - Nursing Clinical Practice Capstone for the RN-BSN Track where students apply principles of patient safety, quality improvement, interprofessional teamwork, informatics, leadership and evidence- based research to nursing practice in a variety of clinical settings. For example, students complete an as signment assessing safety, quality, and high reliability characteristics of the organization. Based on their assessment, they identify attributes that are excellent with rationale and attributes that require improvement with rationale. From their assessmen t and evidence- based literature review they develop a plan with measurable outcomes to evaluate the plan. Other examples available in the Virtual Resource Room . A sample plan of study can be found on the UK CON website . Master's Program The MSN curriculum builds on the knowledge, skills and experience gained at the baccalaureate level. Students complete either the five- semester, full -time plan of study or the eight -semester, part -time plan of study. The curriculum has 38 credits hours whi ch build in complexity as the student progresses through the program. The curriculum consists of both didactic and practicum courses to assist in the achievement of the MSN Essentials and the MSN program outcomes. The core of the curriculum includes theory , research, leadership, and evidence- based practice. The students complete nine credit hours of practicum focusing on leading change, healthy work environments, and completing their capstone project. The curriculum culminates in NUR 660 - MSN Capstone Course where the student applies theory, principles, and processes learned during the program, which leads to a written proposal and oral presentation on an identified practice issue and the evidence- based innovation to address the issue. Since we have not a student enrolled in this an example is not available to include. The sample plans of study are available on the UK CON website . DNP Program The DNP curriculum is logically structured and builds on the knowledge, skills and experience gained at the previous level as well as the NTF criteria, NONPF Core & Specialty Core and AONE guidelines to achieve the expected outcomes. Students in the BSN -DNP bu ild on the baccalaureate level and complete either the eight - semester, full-time plan of study or a 14- or 11-semester, part-time plan of study. Students in the BSN-DNP entry have six population foci from which to choose. These include: Adult Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner ; Family Nurse Practitioner ; Pediatric Acute Care Nurse Practitioner; Pediatric P rimary Care Nurse Practitioner ; Psychiatric -Mental Health Nurse Practitioner ; and Executive Leadership in Health Care. The BSN -DNP curriculum for the nurse practitioner tracks consists of both didactic (core and specialty) and clinical (specialty) courses (74 credit hours) to assist in the achievement of the DNP Essentials, NOPF Core & Specialty Core and the DNP program outcomes. For example, BSN-DNP students are expected to have coursework in research/evidence- based practice, theory, health assessment, pathophysiology, and pharmacology in their baccalaureate program. That coursework provides the foundation for NUR 915 (Evaluating Evidence for Research and Evidence -Based Practice), NUR 924 (Concepts, Theories, and Models for Advanced Practice Nursing), NUR 923 (Applications of Advanced Health Assessment), NUR 921 (Pathophysiology) and NUR 922 (Advanced Pharmacology for Advanced Practice Nurses) courses in the BSN -DNP option. The concepts learned in those courses are reinforced in the specialty courses. For example, in the PMHNP courses students evaluate the evidence to identify best practices for the treatment of selected mental health disorders. The BSN -DNP curricul um for the executive leadership track consists of both didactic (core and specialty) and clinical (specialty) courses (67 credit hours) to assist in the achievement of the DNP Essentials, AONE guidelines and DNP program outcomes. The curriculum culminates in NUR 910 - DNP Project where the student applies knowledge from the program to identify a practi ce issue and intervention, which they implement at a selected site and then they evaluate the outcome of the intervention. The student completes a written paper and oral presentation of their project. Rubrics for the paper and presentation available in the Virtual Resource Room . The MSN -DNP curriculum builds on the knowledge, skills and experience gained at the master's level. 45 Students in the MSN-DNP program complete either the six-semester, full-time plan of study or the eight -semester, part-time plan of study. The curriculum has 38-44 credit hours depending on the track. Students in the MSN-DNP entry have seven population foci to choose. These include: Adult Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner ; Family Nurse Practitioner ; Pediatric Acute Care Nurse Practitioner; Pediatric Primary Care Nurse Practitioner ; Psychiatric -Mental Health Nurse Practitioner ; Executive Leadership in Health Care and Clinical Leadership in Health Care . Students take the same didactic and clinical course s as do the BSN -DNP students. The curriculum culminates in NUR 910 - DNP Project, where the student applies knowledge from the program to identify a practice issue and intervention, which they implement at a selected site and then evaluate the outcome of t he intervention. The student completes a written paper and oral presentation of their project. Rubrics for the paper and presentation available in the Virtual Resource Room . Post-Graduate APRN Certificate Program The Post-Graduate APRN Certificate curriculum builds on the knowledge, skills, and experiences at either the master's or doctoral level. The curriculum consists of both specialty didactic and clinical courses (19- 22 credit hours). Students are integrated into the specialty cours es with the DNP students for the respective population foci. Students choose one of the following nurse practitioner tracks: Acute Care Nurse Practitioner; Family Nurse Practitioner ; Pediatric Acute Care Nurse Practitioner ; Pediatric Primary Care Nurse Practitioner; and Psychiatric - Mental Health Nurse Practitioner , or Executive Leadership . Students complete the Post-Graduate APRN Certificate program in either four semesters, including the Advanced Pathophysiology, Advanced Pharmacology for Advanced Practice Nurses and Applications of Advanced Health Assessment, or three semesters if they have previously taken these courses. Students in the Executive Leadership track complete the program in three semesters. III-G. Teaching -learning practices: support the achievement of expected student outcomes; consider the needs and expectations of the identified community of interest; and expose students to individuals with diverse life experiences, perspectives, and backgrounds. Elaboration: Teaching -learning practices (e.g., simulation, lecture, flipped classroom, case studies) in all environments (e.g., virtual, classroom, clinical experiences, distance education, laboratory) support achievement of expected student outcomes identified in course, unit, and/or level objectives. Teaching -learning practices are appropriate to the student population (e.g., adult learners, second - language students, students in a post -graduate APRN certificate program), consider the needs of the program -identified community of interest, and broaden student perspectives. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The BSN, MSN, DNP, and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate curricula and teaching learning practices are appropriate to the student population and the needs of the identified community of interest (COI). The CON has defined the COI as students, faculty, consumers, supporters, partners (agency personnel ), and alumni. Baccalaureate Program To meet the diverse leaning styles of our students, faculty use a variety of teaching -learning activities to facilitate mastery of nursing content and psychomotor skills. These include the use of face- to-face lecture, flipped classroom, case studies, clinical experiences, and simulated patient experiences. Face-to-face classroom lecture experiences allow the student to directly interact with the instructor in real time, which facilitates clarification of concepts and prompt answering of student questions. Utilizing the flipped classroom allows students to listen to the l ecture prior to class to prepare for the classroom activity. Classroom activities are intended to provide opportunities for the student to gain a deeper understanding of what is being taught, apply concepts to clinical situations, and/or problem -solve usin g a systemic scientific process. In addition, it provides the classroom instructor with a means to evaluate student learning. For example, traditional and ABSN students in NUR 301 - (Family Centered Care of Adults with Common Health Problems), are required to listen to narrated PowerPoint presentations (voice- overs) prior to classroom activities. The purpose of this activity is to prepare students for interactive, application work during class time such as discussions of unfolding case studies, critical thinking, and clinical reasoning activities. An audience response system is used for real -time assessments of knowledge and content reinforcement. Another example is NUR 413 (Synthesis of Clinical Knowledge for Nursing 46 Practice) where nursing concepts from th e completed curriculum are put into practice in this capstone course. Students are paired with a nurse preceptor as they complete 225 hours of direct patient care in a nursing specialty area of interest to them. University writing and presentation requirements for graduation are finished in the Synthesis course. Clinical Environment Consistent with Kentucky Board of Nursing guidelines, undergraduate nursing students are guided through their clinical experiences by clinical instructors. Undergraduate clinical group sizes vary from eight students per instructor to no more than 10. Clinical group size is based on the total number of students in the course, the level and complexity of the course in the curriculum, and clinical s ite factors. The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post-Graduate APRN Certificate programs have access to a wide variety of inpatient and community -based clinical sites within the immediate area. The CON has extensive clinical site agreements with high quality clinical facilities for student clinical placements throughout the area. Examples available in the Virtual Resource Room . Clinical sites are evaluated annually and are reviewed by the Associate and Assistant Deans for the respective programs, the undergrad uate program committee, MSN & DNP program committee, and track coordinators. Examples available in the Virtual Resource Room . Computer Lab Computer labs are available throughout the UK campus. A large onsite computer laboratory is available for all students on weekdays. In addition, the CON building is a wireless environment, allowing students to connect to the Internet using personal electronic devices from anywhere in the building. The computer laboratory on the 6th floor of the CON building was expanded to provide increased seating and computers for classroom and testing purposes. The web- based Canvas® Learning Platform is widely used throughout UK and at the CON at all program levels. This platform facilitates synchronous and asynchronous inform ation sharing between faculty -to- students and student -to-student. Distance Education The RN -BSN option is delivered in an online format of distance education to meet the needs of the working adult learner. The flexibility inherent in distance education m akes it an attractive educational option for the adult learner who has family and work responsibilities. Distance education is consistent with adult learning theory, which is based on the view that adults are mature, motivated, self -directed, independent, and responsible learners who are learner -centered rather than teacher- centered (Knowles, Andragogical Model). For example, students complete NUR 453 (Nursing Practice Capstone for Registered Nurses) and collaborate with faculty to identify clinical practicum sites and specific learning activities. During the practicum, students complete content modules and create an APA -style paper and presentation on topics related to their practicum experience. Activities for the assignment may include analys is/revision/preparation of patient teaching or documentation materials, involvement in nursing education programs for staff development, assessing/revising management functions, changing a policy, quality improvement projects, or a proposal for a pilot research study. Students in the RN -BSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs, including those attending the UKCON- NHC off -campus site, have access to the same resources onsite and through their University of Kentucky -assigned "LinkBlue" account as well. For example, students have electronic access to the UK Library system, which includes the full array of electronic textbooks and journals, Cochrane Databases, Ebsco Host, PubMed search engine for peer- reviewed literature, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), UptoDate, to name a few . Students have access to the CON librarian who is available to assist and coach the students either in groups or individually on literature searches. The librarian is also available for onsite and online tutorials, or appointments can be scheduled for more in -depth sessions and assistance with curriculum/course specific literature/resource searches. Specific activities that the librarian has assisted students with include: formulating literature sea rch strategies; providing fast interlibrary loans; helping set up Search Alerts, an automated process of checking for new results that drop into the students' email boxes; and encouraging nurses to subscribe to eTOCs, whereby the tables of contents of new issues of targeted journals drop into the students' email boxes, and Access Medicine. MSN, DNP & Post -Graduate APRN Certificate Programs Teaching -learning practices in the MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs have been developed to meet the specific needs of the adult learner. Flexibility of scheduling, access to faculty and online 47 resources are important components of the programs. The faculty use a variety of teaching -learning methods, which are used in each track and course to acc ommodate different learning styles. These activities include narrated lectures, faculty -designed modules, invited speakers, small group work, exams, presentations, case studies, threaded discussion, and writing assignments. The MSN program is delivered in an online format. The teaching -learning activities used by the faculty in the MSN program include narrated lectures, small group work, invited speakers, presentations, exams, writing assignments and faculty designed modules. For example, in NUR 919 Quality and Safety in Nursing and Healthcare, students complete a discussion board assignment to evaluate quality improvement tools and resources from professional organizations, government agencies, and accrediting bodies. Another example is in NUR 660 (M SN Capstone Course) where the student applies theory, principles, and processes learned during the program which leads to a written proposal and oral presentation on an identified practice issue and the evidence- based innovation to address the issue. The DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs are delivered through an online- immersion format. Students attend on -campus sessions twice a semester to complete course requirements that are better suited for face- to-face instruction. For example, in N UR 923 Applications of Advanced Health Assessment, students are evaluated on their performance of a head-to-toe assessment. Another example, in NUR 966 Diagnosis and Management of Psychiatric Illnesses in Adults and Elderly, students are evaluated on completing a diagnostic interview on a simulated patient and developing a plan of care and evaluation plan based on the results. Students have the opportunity to hear from UKHC experts and other health profession colleges both internal and external to UK. In addition, more than one teaching -learning method is often used to assist students grasp complex concepts. For example, in NUR 941 and NUR 942 (Acute -Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Seminar I and II), the content on suturing, lumbar puncture, central line placement, and respiratory failure is presented as a lecture and then students complete a lab and simulation experience for each. In addition, significant attention is paid to scholarly writing throughout the program, as reflected by its emphasis in multiple courses throughout the program and the DNP project. The ePortfolio and assessment management system - Digication - is another resource used by all DNP students throughout the course of their studies for storing their scholarly products, examples of clinical accomplishments and updated curriculum vitae. Digication remains accessible to students ' post-graduation and serves as an example of their scholarly work during the job interviewing process. Students have the opportu nity to formally evaluate their courses and instructors every semester to provide feedback on the usefulness of teaching -learning strategies. Given that students do not meet on a weekly basis, an in -depth orientation has been developed for incoming students. This is designed to keep students informed about the program and the CON, obtain feedback from them, and nurture faculty -student relationships, thereby enhancing learning. Students receive information about several CON student resources during orientation, including library resources, IT CON consultants, the writing specialist, the UK Writing Center, Graduate Student Services, and the variety of software and platforms that will be used in the program. Community of Interest Teaching -learning practices take into consideration the needs of the COI. The curriculum and teaching - learning practices within the BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs are designed and revised to meet the expectations of local, regional, and national nursing administrators regarding their need for competent graduates. An example that illustrates the teaching -learning practices consider the needs of the COI is the request the CON received in 2018 to su pport Licensed Practical Nurses (LPN) currently employed in the UKHC system obtain their BSN. The CON held focus groups with the LPNs to determine their interest in completing their BSN. Overwhelmingly, nurses responded that they were interested, and needed an online delivery model to advance their education while working. The ABSN track, which is delivered in a hybrid format, was developed to include the LPN -BSN students. The first ten LPN -BSN students began their course work in fall 2 020. Another example is the request the CON received from several hospital administrators to support their BSN -prepared nurse managers in earning their MSN degree. Based on their feedback and interest, the CON developed the MSN program in Healthcare System s Leadership. The program is delivered in an online format to accommodate the working professionals. The first ten MSN students began their course work in fall 2019. III-H. The curriculum includes planned clinical practice experiences that: enable students to integrate new knowledge and demonstrate attainment of program outcomes; foster interprofessional collaborative practice; and 48 are evaluated by faculty. Elaboration: To prepare students for a practice profession, each track in each degree program and each track in the post -graduate APRN certificate program affords students the opportunity to develop professional competencies and to integrate new knowledge in practice settings aligned to the educational preparation. Clinical practice experie nces include opportunities for interprofessional collaboration. Clinical practice experiences are provided for students in all programs, including those with distance education offerings. Clinical practice experiences align with student and program outcome s. These experiences are planned, implemented, and evaluated to ensure students are competent to function as members of interprofessional teams at the level for which they are being prepared. Programs that have a direct care focus (including, but not limi ted to, post -licensure baccalaureate and nurse educator tracks) provide direct care experiences designed to advance the knowledge and expertise of students in a clinical area of practice. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The curricula for the BSN, MSN, DNP and Post-Graduate APRN Certificate programs have planned clinical practice experiences that enable students to integrate knowledge and demonstrate attainment of program outcomes. Students in the Traditional and ABSN tracks have clinical experiences in adult health, obstetrics, pediatrics, psychiatric -mental, and public health, which culminates in the last semester with the synthesis clinical. The students are evaluated by the faculty in each clinical experience. Mid-rotation and final evaluations are used to assess student performance with remediation activities for poor performance at any point in time. In the traditional and ABSN track, for example, a nine- item clinical evaluation form is used to assess student performance at mid-rotation and at the end of the course. Clinical faculty and nurse preceptors send performance data to the faculty course coordinator for evaluation and assignment of a final course grade. In clinical courses, faculty provide a description of clinical expectations in course syllabi, provide students and preceptors with specific clinical learning objectives and evaluation criteria, engage in mid-rotation and final clinical performance evaluation, and share clinical performance outcomes with students as they are assessed. Evidence -based clinical assignment for patient encounters III-I. Individual student performance is evaluated by the faculty and reflects achievement of expected student outcomes. Evaluation policies and procedures for individual student performance are defined and consistently applied. 50 Elaboration: Evaluation of student performance is consistent with expected student outcomes. Grading criteria are clearly defined for each course, communicated to students, and applied consistently. Processes exist by which the evaluation of individual student performance is communicated to students. In instances where preceptors facilitate students' clinical learning experiences, faculty may seek input from preceptors regarding student performance, but ultimately faculty are responsible for evaluation of indivi dual student outcomes. The requirement for evaluation of student clinical performance by qualified faculty applies to all students in all programs. Faculty evaluation of student clinical performance may be accomplished through a variety of mechanisms. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Faculty utilize a variety of assessment strategies to evaluate student performance at the course level for achievement of the student learning outcomes (SLO). Each course syllabus identifies the specific course and clinical SLOs expected to be mastered for successful completion of the course, evaluation components and methodology, contribution of each compo nent to the course grade, the criteria used to evaluate student performance, grading scale and clinical evaluation instrument needed. Course syllabi available in the Virtual Resource Room. The academic performance of students in the BSN programs of study are consistently evaluated in every course in the CON based on the course's objectives that reflect individual student learning outcomes for that course. The faculty use a variety of evaluation methods throughout the curriculum, including written examinati ons, written papers, group, and individual presentations. Using a variety of evaluation methods allows faculty to assess various aspects of student learning, such as comprehension of relevant content, ability to apply knowledge, and analytic and problem -solving abilities. The course syllabus is the contract between the course faculty and students for establishing expected outcomes. All syllabi include course student learning outcomes, a summary description of the compon ents that contribute to the course grade, the numerical scale to be used in grading and its relationship to letter grades, and an explicit statement of the weight for each component of the grade. Students are oriented to the syllabus on the first day of class, and the syllabus is made available to them at that time, either by hard copy and/or on the course Canvas® platform. By UK policy, all undergraduate students receive a formal midterm grade and a final grade, both of which are uploaded into the campus g rade database, allowing students to view their grades. The midterm grade serves to alert students to marginal or failing grades. Students who are failing at midterm are informed by the course instructor. The student's academic advisor and the CON's student success advisor are also alerted through the myUK Grading Portal. The BSN program grading scale was vetted and approved by the Undergraduate Program Committee and the Undergraduate Faculty group. All courses are required to use the approved grading scale. Students must earn a minimum exam average of 76/100 (changed to 73/100 summer 2020) to pass courses that use examinations in the evaluation process. If a written assignment or project increases the overall course grade to 76% (chang ed to 73/100 summer 2020) or higher, but the examination mean remains less than the passing standard, the rule applies, and the student does not pass the course. The University of Kentucky mandates composition and oral presentation skill development for un dergraduates. To meet the Graduate Composition and Communication Requirement (GCCR) mandate, students must pass any GCCR assignment imbedded into a course. Additionally, all students must pass medication mathematics testing with 100% mastery to pass clinic al courses that assign this work. These grading procedures are outlined in course syllabi and in the Undergraduate Student Handbook outlined in the Undergraduate Student Handbook 2020 -2021 (pp. 38). The BSN program grading policy is as follows: A = 90 -100 B = 80 - < 90 C = 73 - < 80 D = 68 - < 73 E - < 68 All BSN clinical courses have student clinical performance evaluation forms that vary in design and focus based on the type of clinical course; however, all are consistent with the course objectives. The student clinical performance evaluation forms are made available to students at the beginning of the semester to ensure that students have a clear understanding of performance expectations. Clinical course syllabi contain clinical policies and procedures related to student performance, such as clinical attendance and professional role expectations, dress code, clinical evaluatio n and grading process, consequences for cheating and plagiarism, and CPR and immunization requirements. Clinical instructors teach, observe, and evaluate the clinical performance of each 51 student and provide a clinical evaluation at the end of each clinical rotation in each course. Clinical course coordinators may seek input from the clinical faculty or preceptors for student evaluation and serve as resources for clinical faculty to assure consistent application of the grading criteria. The course coordinators are responsible for collation of all grading criteria and determination of the final grades based on the course criteria. Students are formally evaluated by CON clinical instructors at two points during the semester -- midterm (formative evalu ation) and the end of the semester (summative evaluation). Students in the MSN, DNP, and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs are consistently evaluated in each individual course by the faculty member who teaches the course. Grading policies adhered to in the CON are those of UK as outlined in the DNP/Certificate Graduate Student Handbook and the MSN/PhD Graduate Student Handbook . The MSN, DNP, and Post -Graduate Certificate programs grading policy uses the standard University grading scale: A = 90 - 100; B = 80 - 89; C = 73 - 79. Grading expectations for courses are clearly stated in the syllabus and are based on assignments that facilitate achievement of course SLOs. Students are evaluated using a variety of methods including written papers, class participation, presentations, group projects, computer -based assignments, course examinations, and case study analyses. Students in specialty courses with clinical components follows the NONPF- NTF criteria for faculty regarding student assignment ratio and preceptor qualifications. Alt hough preceptors have input into the students' performance, faculty retain responsibility for assigning a grade for students' clinical performance. For example, a minimum of once a semester, faculty in the Nurse Practitioner tracks evaluate students in the clinical setting. Evidence of formative evaluation about individual student performance and progression in the program include individual student electronic transcript information that shows course grade assignments and in the plans of study found in individual student records located in the Graduate Student Affairs office. Examples of summative evaluation of individual student learning include published papers by students enrolled in the program, IRB applications, and final DNP Project reports that all students are required to complete as part of their degree requirements.
