The curriculum and teaching -learning practices are evaluated at regularly scheduled intervals, and evaluation data are used to foster ongoing improvement. Elaboration: Faculty use data from faculty and student evaluation of teaching -learning practices to inform decisions that facilitate the achievement of student outcomes. Such evaluation activities may be formal or informal, formative, or summative. The curriculum is regularly evaluated by faculty and 52 revised as appropriate. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Curriculum and teaching learning practices in the BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate programs are evaluated at regularly scheduled intervals to foster ongoing improvement as per the CON Systematic Process for Program Evaluation . Faculty, preceptors, clinical sites, courses, and the curriculum are regularl y evaluated by faculty, with feedback solicited from other communities of interest as appropriate. Students evaluate the faculty at the end of each semester. The online surveys are anonymous, and data are collected electronically. Student evaluations are a lso submitted as part of faculty performance evaluations. Clinical sites and clinical preceptors are evaluated by the student at the completion of the rotation via a computer- based survey or paper survey. Examples available in the Virtual Resource Room . The data are reviewed by the track coordinators, and the Associate and Assistant Dean for Undergraduate and DNP programs to make informed decisions on whether to use in the future. In addition, key stakeholders (executive leadership) for academic clinical pa rtnerships (UKHC, NHC and Select Medical ) are engaged annually with curricular and teaching -learning practices. Curriculum changes in the BSN, ABSN and RN -BSN tracks occur for a variety of reasons including, for example, to address current trends and needs of our clinical partners, evaluations, and revisions in the professional standards and guidelines used by the program. Faculty receive course and teaching evaluation data from information submitted by students through the University's Teacher Course Eval uation (TCE) system each semester. Course changes are made when student suggestions are feasible and advisable. For example, when students recommended payment for clinical work in a practicum course, the suggestion was not feasible and was not acted upon. In another instance, students requested changes to an assignment that improved the learning experience and increased assignment clarity; therefore, the changes were made. The Undergraduate Program Committee evaluates all BSN courses on a three- year cycle. Members of the committee and course faculty engage in the formal process using standardized evaluation forms. Recommendations for improvement are shared with the course faculty and are incorporated into future courses when warranted. Data from course reviews are stored in the undergraduate administrative office and in UK Shares (virtual storage) . Curriculum evaluation plans are formal and are approved at College and University levels. Evaluations of Program Student Learning Outcomes (PSLO) occur on a three -to-five-year cycle and are updated as required by the University. For example, the PSLO evaluation plan for the 2020- 2025 cycle was submitted to UK's Strategic Planning and Institutional Effectiveness office in July 2020. The MSN program has not undergone a curriculum revision since it is new. The curriculum will be reviewed and revised as is the standard for the BSN, DNP and Post-Graduate APRN Certificate programs. The data obtained from the evaluations will be used to inform changes in the curriculum. Curriculum changes in the DNP program occur to meet the needs of the Community of Interest as well as changes to the professional standards and guidelines. All tracks adhere to the NONPF core competences which were revised in 2017. As a result, the curriculum was reviewed to assure congruence with the revised competences. Another example is in NUR 909 (Proposal Development), which has been revised to better align the DN P Project Guidelines and to assist the students in completing their written proposal in a more timely manner. Another example is UKHC and NHC leadership requesting to reduce the length of time for onsite didactic. Faculty implemented an immersion model of meeting three blocked days at the beginning of semester and two blocked days at the end of the semester starting summer 2018. Although still under review, the UKHC Nurse Residency Program (NRP) Advisory Board has recommended two strategic efforts to strengthen efforts for integration of scholarly activities and professional advancement through higher education. A model to bridge UK College of Nursing BSN student research projects to NRP projects and then transition to UK College of Nursing DNP project s continues to be under discussion. The other recommendation is to obtain University approval to award academic credit for the UKHC Nurse Residency Program. Dr. Jessica Wilson, co- chair of the NRP and track coordinator of the RN to BSN program, is actively engaged with curricular changes to build confidence and solidify a foundation for a RN -BSN program of study at UK College of Nursing (at UKHC any new hire Associate Degree RN must complete a RN -BSN program of study 53 within 5 years). Selected NRP minutes av ailable In the Virtual Resource Room . STANDARD III Summary: Curriculum and Teaching -Learning Practices Levels of Strength of Quality Strong Strength of Quality The University of Kentucky (state/senate approval) and UK Healthcare (clinical placement) have supported the College of Nursing's mission to advance innovative curricular initiatives for undergraduate and graduate education. The College of Nursing has an impressive academic portfolio of student outcome excellence including NCLEX boar d rates, APRN certification rates, and graduation rates. The College of Nursing has established highly collaborative learning environments to advance simulated learning (the Clinical Simulations and Learning Center is under review for full accreditation) a nd interprofessional health education (Center for Interprofessional Health Education programming benefits from long -standing nursing faculty leadership). The College of Nursing provides resources and fully supports faculty for curricular innovation for undergraduate (such as MED -VET BSN track) and graduate education (such as the only Acute Care Pediatric NP track in Kentucky). Moderate to High Strength of Quality The College of Nursing has fully engaged and committed community of interest partners to advise and recommend strategies to advance undergraduate (such as the 100% online LPN to BSN track) and graduate curricular innovation (such as returning the MSN degree option). The College of Nursing has a strong commitment and resources to su pport professional development to advance curricular and learning practice excellence such as certified online teachers, instructional design teams, writing specialists and faculty with expertise with student mental health and wellness. The College of Nurs ing has a strong commitment from faculty to ensure undergraduate and graduate curricular initiatives are congruent with the College mission, professional standards of practice and needs/expectations of the community of interest. The College of Nursing re cognizes the significant impact of the global pandemic on the mental health and wellness of students will require on -going efforts to adjust curricular efforts and learning practices (extending program of study /honoring hours for COVID vaccine distributio n campaign). Low to Moderate Strength of Quality The College of Nursing recognizes the upcoming release of the new AACN Essentials and new DNP study will require on - going efforts to adjust curricular efforts and learning practices (crosswalk curricula for gaps to address for undergraduate and graduate education). The College of Nursing recognizes to increase engagement with graduate students with the Center of Interprofessional Health Education programming and Clinical Simulation and Learning Center will require on -going efforts to support. 54 Standard IV Program Effectiveness: Assessment and Achievement of Program Outcomes The program is effective in fulfilling its mission and goals as evidenced by achieving expected program outcomes. Program outcomes include student outcomes, faculty outcomes, and other outcomes identified by the program. Data on program effectiveness are used to foster ongoing program improvement. IV-A. A systematic process is used to determine program effe ctiveness. Elaboration: The program (baccalaureate, master's, DNP, and/or post -graduate APRN certificate) uses a systematic process to obtain relevant data to determine program effectiveness. The process: is written, is ongoing, and exists to determine ac hievement of program outcomes; is comprehensive (i.e., includes completion, licensure, certification, and employment rates, as required by the U.S. Department of Education; faculty outcomes; and other program outcomes); identifies which quantitative and/or qualitative data are collected to assess achievement of the program outcomes; includes timelines for data collection, review of expected and actual outcomes, and analysis; and is periodically reviewed and revised as appropriate. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON utilizes a systematic plan for determining program effectiveness. The CON Systematic Process for Program Evaluation (SPPE) is the overarching document that outlines the process of evaluation used to facilitate the attainment of the BSN, MSN, DNP and Post-Graduate APRN Certificate program outcomes. The SPPE was revised by the Director of Accreditation and Strategic Outcomes in 2019 to align with CCNE Accreditation Standards. It was approved by the Dean's Council in February 2020, and the Faculty Organization in 2019. Minutes available in the Virtual Resource Room . The SPPE is organized by the CCNE Standards and Key Elements and the UK CON Strategic Plan indicates the responsible party, evidence collected, analysis, and purpose. The SPPE identifies regular data collection activi ties and sources including individual and aggregate student outcomes as reflected in Table IVA -1: Selected SPPE Data Collection Activities. The MSN and Post - Graduate APRN Certificate programs will continue to collect the same metrics that have been routinely collected in the BSN and DNP programs. This includes quantitative data such as completion rates, employment rates and certification rates as indicated and program satisfaction. The evaluation plan includes a timeframe for data collection. The Dir ector of Accreditation and Strategic Outcomes collects, aggregates, and analyzes the information and provides a report to the CON Dean and respective Associate and Assistant Dean. They review the data to determine if the identified benchmark is met. If the benchmark is not met the data are further reviewed by the CON Dean, respective Associate and Assistant Dean and program faculty to determine next steps. Evidence that the SPPE process is implemented to determine program effectiveness is illustrated in the CON Dean Calendar meetings, program committee minutes, and the Dean's Council minutes. Full -time BSN -DNP students are expected to complete the program within five calendar years from time of admission. Full -time MSN-DNP students are expected to complete the program within five calendar years from time of admission. Students in the Post -Graduate APRN Certifi cate program students are expected to complete the program within two calendar years from time of admission. Employment rates demonstrate program effectiveness. This key element is not applicable to a degree or certificate program that does not yet have individuals who have completed the program. Elaboration: The program demonstrates achievement of required outcomes regarding employment rates. The employment rate is provided separately for each degree program (baccalaureate, master's, and DNP) and the post -graduate APRN certificate program. Data are collected within 12 months of program completion. Specifically, employment data are collected at the time of program completion or at any time within 12 months of program completion. The employment rate is 70% or higher. However, if the employment rate is less than 70%, the employment rate is 70% or higher when excluding graduates who have elected not to be employed. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The programs demonstrate achievement of required outcomes regarding employment rates. Students in the BSN program provide employment information on the Skyfactor® End -of-Program Assessment as well as the University Senior Survey. The BSN Program employmen t rate for the past 3 years - total number of students invited to complete the survey = 693; Responded to survey= 304; of those who responded 135 answered the employment question; of those who answered the employment question= 129 indicated they had employ ment after graduation. The employment rate of those who responded was 96% which exceeds the CCNE benchmark of 70%. During the Quarterly Academic Nurse Practice Collaborative meetings, areas of opportunity were discussed for recruitment of graduates to UKHC . The MSN program has not graduated any students at this time but are on target to graduate in May 2021 and employment rates will be monitored and evaluated appropriately as is our standard. Students in the DNP program provide employment information on t he Skyfactor® End -of-Program Assessment as well as the CON post -graduation survey. The DNP Program employment rate for the past 3 years - total number of students invited to complete the survey = 216; the number who responded to the survey = 100; of those w ho responded 100 answered the employment question; of those who answered the employment question = 100 indicated they had employment after graduation. The employment rate of those who responded was 100% which exceeds the CCNE benchmark of 70%. To increase the response rate, students receive three email reminders to complete the end- of-program assessment and two reminders for the post -graduation survey. The most notable example of achieving successful employment rates in the DNP program occurred during the 7 -year partnership between Norton Healthcare (NHC) in Louisville, Kentucky, and the CON. This academic -clinical partnership was designed to prepare approximately 100 BSN prepared staff nurses as DNP graduates for APRN board eligibility. An underlining comm itment by NHC nursing leadership was to retain the DNP graduates in the organization and utilize them according to their certified specialty area. The innovation of this partnership and the DNP student outcomes have been widely distributed during key stake holder meetings such as the UKHC -CON workforce meetings, the Dean's Advisory Board meetings, as well as through faculty national presentations and publications. Stakeholder minutes and CON faculty publications related to the UKCON -NHC partnership are available in the Virtual Resource Room. IV-F. Data regarding completion, licensure, cer tification, and employment rates are used, as appropriate, to foster ongoing program improvement. This key element is applicable if one or more of the following key elements is applicable: Key Element IV- B (completion), Key Element IV -C (licensure), Key Element IV -D (certification), and Key Element IV - E (employment). Elaboration: The program uses outcome data (completion, licensure, certification, and employment) 60 for improvement. Discrepancies between actual and CCNE expected outcomes (p rogram completion rates 70%, licensure pass rates 80%, certification pass rates 80%, employment rates 70%) inform areas for improvement. Changes to the program to foster improvement and achievement of program outcomes, as appropriate, are deliberate, ongoi ng, and analyzed for effectiveness. Faculty are engaged in the program improvement process. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The pass rates for licensure exams are shared with faculty by the Assistant Dean of the BSN program and the track coordinators. Given the positive outcomes of exceeding the CCNE benchmark of 80%, no changes have been deemed needed. The certification pass rates are shared with the faculty by the track coordinators and the Assistant Dean of the DNP and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate program. Overall, the certification pass rates meet or exceed the CCNE benchmark of 80%. The first -time pass rate for a single year in the AGACNP track was below the CCNE benchmark for 2018 at 75% for those who took the exam. First-time pass rates In the PMHNP and PNP-AC tracks met the CCNE benchmarks, 80% and 83% respectively, in 2017. We will continue to monitor first - time pass rates in all tracks closely and ad dress immediately if they fall below the 80% CCNE benchmark. The completion rates for the traditional BSN, ABSN, RN -BSN, DNP, and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate Programs are shared with the faculty by the Associate/Assistant Dean of the respective programs in faculty meetings. Given the positive outcomes of those who responded, no changes have been deemed needed. The MSN program has not had anyone complete the program, but the students are on target to graduate in May 2021 and will be monitored and evaluated appropriately as is our standard. The employment rates for the BSN, ABSN, DNP, and Post -Graduate APRN Certificate Programs are shared with the faculty by the Assistant Dean of the respective programs. Even though the outcomes were positive for those who responded, it was deemed necessary for faculty to email reminders to their students to complete the assessment to increase the response rate. The MSN program will have th eir first graduates in May 2021 and will be monitored and evaluated appropriately as is our standard. All data are shared with the CON Dean and the Associate Dean of the respective program. The data are reviewed in the Deans Council, which provides input if any changes are deemed needed. IV-G. Aggregate faculty outcomes demonstrate program effectiveness. Elaboration : The program demonstrates achievement of expected faculty outcomes. In order to demonstrate program effectiveness, outcomes are consistent w ith and contribute to achievement of the program's mission and goals and are congruent with institution and program expectations. Expected faculty outcomes: are identified for the faculty as a group; specify expected levels of achievement for the faculty as a group; and 1.reflect expectations of faculty in their roles. Actual faculty outcomes are compared to expected levels of achievement. Actual faculty outcomes are presented in the aggregate. If expected faculty outcomes vary for different groups of faculty (full- time, part -time, adjunct, tenured, non -tenured, or other), actual faculty outcomes may be presented separately for each different group of faculty. Program Response: The BS N, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. Faculty outcomes are associated with the expectation of the faculty appointment (title series, rank, educational degree) as well as teaching effectiveness, scholar ship (research and/or scholarly activities), practice and/or service. Expected faculty outcomes reflect the CON mission and are congruent with the overall mission of UK. Faculty outcomes, individually and in the aggregate, demonstrate program effectiveness and are 61 presented in the four major categories that represent the CON " statements of evidence " for appointment and advancement . Although part -time and adjunct faculty support program effectiveness, they are only included in teaching effectiveness outcomes and not in the scholarly activities or practice/service outcomes. Faculty outcomes/expectations are integrated as part of the Annual Performance Evaluation with the appropriate Associate Dean for individualized strategies discussed f or professional growth and faculty advancement. The Associate Dean of the respective program reviews the faculty member's documents, writes comments, and then schedules an appointment to discuss the evaluation. A faculty member who wishes to be considered for high merit (recognition over and above merit with monetary compensation as budget allows) must provide additional documentation to the reporting Associate Dean summarizing academic achievements exceeding expectation designated by their title series and rank. If a faculty member appeals the decision for high merit then the information is sent to the Promotion, Appointment and Tenure Advisory (PATA) Committee to review and make a recommendation to the Dean. Elaboration: The program uses faculty outcome data for improvement. 2.Faculty outcome data are used to promote ongoing program improvement. Discrepancies between actual and expected outcomes inform areas for improvement. Changes to foster ach ievement of faculty outcomes, as appropriate, are deliberate, ongoing, and analyzed for effectiveness. Faculty are engaged in the program improvement process. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post -Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance wit h this Key Element. The CON's annual evaluation plan (SPPE) includes overall faculty effectiveness outcomes and is reviewed annually for faculty approval. Quality improvement plans or curriculum recommendations for changes, based on benchmarks identified by faculty, are developed annually during program committee work in the areas of teaching effectiveness (predominant ly data from TCE and End-of-Program surveys). Individual faculty outcomes, as appropriate, are managed during the Annual Performance Evaluation process with the Associate Dean to promote improvement/advancement with teaching effectiveness, scholarly activi ties, research, practice, and service. Similar to teaching effectiveness outcomes, discrepancies between actual and expected faculty outcomes are managed individually and collectively for scholarly activities, research, practice, and service. For example, tenure- track faculty are expected, and non- tenure track faculty are encouraged to submit poster presentations and from those develop manuscripts. Senior faculty have successfully worked with junior faculty on the development of research proposals for grants, manuscripts, chapters, and presentat ions. The RICH Heart Research Team hosts a week -long summer writing workshop to assist faculty with writing a manuscript for publication. The Office of Nursing Research (ONR) started covering the registration expenses for the writing workshop to advance sc holarship productivity with faculty. In addition, the ONR provides significant assistance with facilitating collaborative research initiatives and guiding the grant writing process both internal and external to the University. 67 All full- time faculty are expected to be engaged in service and all APRN -prepared faculty are supported for faculty practice placement and distribution of effort (DOE)/workload protection. As a function of the Senior Associate Dean's role leading faculty a dvancement initiatives, faculty are kept well informed about faculty service opportunities. Associate Deans work closely with faculty to help strategize best service opportunities that match workload capacity, as faculty service is a component of the perfo rmance review and includes service on committees both internal and external to the CON. The Dean's Council annually discusses faculty plans for service advancement opportunities including representation on national and international committees and boards of professional organizations. Elaboration: The program demonstrates achievement of outcomes other than those related to completion rates (Key Element IV -B), licensure pass rates (Key Element IV -C), certification pass rates (Key Element IV -D), employment rates (Key Element IV -E), and faculty (Key Element IV -G). Program outcomes are defined by the program and incorporate expected levels of achievement. The program describes how outcomes are measured. Actual levels of achievement, when compared to expected levels of achievement, demonstrate that the program, overall, is achieving its outcomes. Program outcomes are appropriate and relevant to the degree and certificate programs offered. Discrepancies between actual and expected outcomes inform areas for improvement. Changes to the program to foster improvement and achievement of program outcomes, as 70 appropriate, are deliberate, ongoing, and analyzed for effectiveness. Faculty are engaged in the program improvement process. Program Response: The BSN, MSN, DNP and Post Graduate Certificate Programs are in compliance with this Key Element. The CON uses data sources such as the graduating senior survey, completion rates, NCLEX® pass rates, certification pass rates, en d of program evaluations, employment rates, Teacher Course Evaluations among others to foster ongoing program improvement. The actual program outcomes are compared to the expected program outcomes to foster ongoing program improvement. Aggregate data are disseminated to the Dean, Associate and Assistant Deans for review. The BSN, MSN, DNP program committees review the outcome data for the respective programs. Discrepancies between actual outcomes and expected outcomes are discussed and strategies for progra m improvement are identified. The information is also shared with the faculty in the respective programs to foster ongoing assessment and overall effectiveness of the identified improvement strategies. Program Satisfaction Although the benchmarks were met for the BSN programs and partially met for the DNP program, efforts will continue to collect the data as it will be different with each graduating class. Due to incomplete surveys in the Post -Graduate APRN Certificate program we were unable to identify discrepancies between the actual and expected outcomes. The MSN program has not had anyone complete the prog ram and efforts will continue to monitor and evaluate as per our standard. For the past 2 -3 years the response rates have been low to moderate for all the programs despite the students receiving four email reminders. The issue has been discussed with progr am faculty who are involved in problem solving it. The end of program surveys contains written feedback that are also used to improve the programs. Examples of strengths the BSN students identified include quality of education, faculty invested in our success, well prepared to be a nurse, structure of program, and availability of faculty to name a few. Examples of opportunities the BSN students identified include need more space in the college, more time in clinical, and more clear communication for incoming students to name a few. Examples of DNP program strengths identified by students included clinical experiences were well organized, program was very structured, program led to personal and professional growth, and collaboration with peers to name a few. Examples of DNP program improvement areas identified by students included more information regarding uploading work to UKnowledge, more focus on clinical experiences, more focus on advanced practice than project, and more education on palliative care to name a few. Teaching Effectiveness The benchmark of all courses and faculty being evaluated each semester was met. The benchmark of a 4.0 or greater on the course evaluation and the teacher evaluation was not met in the BSN, MSN, and DNP/Post - Graduate APRN Certificate programs. The faculty lead in those courses with less than a 4.0 and the faculty with less than a 4.0 for teaching effectiveness meet with the respective Associate Dean. The conversation includes reviewing quantitative and qualitative data to understand the concerns and determine any strategies that may be needed for enhancing outcomes. Specific areas of focus during a teaching effectiveness review by the Associate Deans may include questioning 1) whether changes had been made to the course prior to the semester being evaluated, 2) had the faculty taught the course before, and 3) was this the second consecutive evaluation that the faculty member received a less than 4.0 for the course and/or teaching effectiveness. For example, as reflected in Table IVI-2, it was determined many courses during 2019- 2020 review period had undergone changes in either the delivery and/or the content from the previous semester being taught. Further review revealed the faculty members with less than 4.0 were recommended for a teaching effectiveness/course development plan for su ccess. Selected files available upon request in the Virtual Resource Room . Employer Feedback The benchmark of receiving feedback from employers was met and the CON will continue to monitor for ongoing program improvement opportunities. The feedback was received through a variety of meetings including the previously mentioned key stakeholders: CON -UKHC Workforce meeting, UKHC Nurse Residency Advisory Board meetings, UKHC Strategic Nursing Directo rs meetings, and the UKHC CNE and Dean meetings. Selected minutes and calendar notifications available In the Virtual Resource Room . 71 STANDARD IV Summary: Assessment and Achievement of Program Outcomes Levels of Strength of Quality Strong Strength of Quality The University of Kentucky has supported the College of Nursing's mission for quality assessment and achievement of program outcomes through extensive infrastructure support such as the UK Office of Institutional Effectiveness, the UK Center for Enhancement of Learning and Teaching (CELT), the UK Center for Interprofessional Health Education (CIHE) and the UK HealthCare Nurse Residency Program . The College of Nursing has a strong base of undergraduate honors programming (CIHE, Global Health and Nursing Scholars The College of Nursing has a robust Systematic Process for Program Effectiveness plan (SPPE) and a dedicated team to support data collection, analysis, and distribution of outcomes. The College of Nursing has strong programs of study outcomes that exceed CCNE benchmarks including NCLEX rates, APRN certification rates, graduation rates, and teaching effectiveness rates. The College of Nursing has nationally and internationally known faculty members with highly producti ve programs of scholarship including research grants submissions and awards, presentations, and publications. The College of Nursing has a strong community of interest the include internal and external advisory boards composed of members with diverse backgrounds to provide guidance and recommendations on strategic initiatives. The College of Nursing has stellar faculty with national and international recognition as fellows in professional societies and organizations. The College of Nursing has a strong base of alumni with influential national and international positions of impact as academic nurse leaders, nurse executives and researchers. The College of Nursing has a solid base of enrichment programs to advance student engagement with research, practice, and education. Moderate to High Strength of Quality The College of Nursing has a solid base of faculty engaged in faculty practice within and outside of UK HealthCare. The College of Nursing has a solid base of student engaged in scholarly activities (poster presentations, podium presentations and publications). The College of Nursing has a solid base of BSN student /alumni pursuing graduate nursing education at UK. Low to Moderate Strength of Quality The College of Nursing recognizes assessment platforms/systems for collecting data, analyzing data and reporting data will require structural changes such as a Typhon or Castlebranch platform. The College of Nursing recognizes coordinated efforts for management of the SPPE plan will require process changes including a formalized /separate standing committee for outcomes assessment. The College of Nursing recognizes strategic efforts for management of alumni data will require process/structural changes such as linking re sponsibilities in the Office of Alumni Affairs integrating with the Office of Assessment and Strategic Outcomes. The College of Nursing recognizes efforts for bridging COI input through the UKHC NRP Advisory Board will require intentional efforts for completion of process approval. 72 Appendices 73 Appendices
